logTag.type = "text/javascript"; logTag.src = "/gp/customer-media/du/log.html?ie=UTF8&p=CustomerImage&s=CustomerVideoPlay"; head[0].appendChild(logTag); } if (cv_mo194E31U1IU7RScurrentClick) { return cv_mo194E31U1IU7RScurrentClick(); } } } Length:: 0:33 MinsThe Fujifilm Finepix XP10, newly available in April 2010, is a stylish little ultra-compact camera that invites you to have fun outdoors while taking pictures. It:- is waterproof to 10 ft. under water, perfect for swimming pools, beach, snorkeling (note: do not use in hot water!)- is shockproof up to 3 ft., great for jogging, cycling, or even letting your baby learn to take pictures- is freezeproof down to 14 degrees Fahrenheit (-10 Celsius)- is dustproof- has 12.2 effective megapixels- has 5x optical zoom and features a Fujinon lens for great clarity; lens focal length is 36-180mm in 35mm film camera terms- takes 720p widescreen, VGA or QVGA video- can zoom optically in video mode (but see note on audio recording below)- is really small and weighs just a little over 5 oz. with battery and SDHC card- uses SDHC memory card, no more xD that was championed by Fuji and OlympusI bought a green XP10 because I love spending time in the water. I find that, outdoors during the day, the XP10 takes pictures with excellent clarity and excellent color saturation and contrast. Using fill-in flash in daylight truly enhances the picture. Indoors, because the XP10 lacks Fuji's legendary SuperCCD technology, picture quality is average for a compact or super-compact camera. It does have two natural-scene modes where it boosts the ISO (light sensitivity of the image sensor) at the expense of increased noise. I bought my XP10 to be used outdoors, in the pool and at the beach, so I haven't taken many indoor pics.Video shooting at 720p yields smooth, clear HD video clips. BTW, video size is limited only by the 2GB FAT32 file size limit -- this means even if you pop in a 16GB SDHC card, the longest video clip can only go up to 2GB in file size, due to the limit imposed by the FAT32 file system. Video is recorded as motion JPEG in an AVI container, so it can be played on many, many devices, at the expense of slightly larger file sizes than a more compact format like MPEG-2 or MPEG-4.While you can zoom optically -- a feature that every digital camera should have -- audio recording's volume level is lowered during zooming. Instead, the camera picks up some noise from the lens mechanism and that noise overwhelms the ambient sounds you want to record, which can be annoying when played back on a large TV. My advise is to use zooming sparingly during video mode. If you want great video recording on a compact digital camera, you should get a Sony or Canon or Panasonic camera (be prepared to pay a lot more for the waterproof feature, though).Anyway, my sample video clip shows how the camera works under water. The video resolution was set to QVGA (320x240) for easy upload to Amazon, but you should be able to see the amazing clarity both in and out of water.In summary, the XP10 is a great waterproof, shockproof camera that every water enthusiast should bring along to record fun memories.

Reviews.Title: Touted As Waterproof; Warranty Says Otherwise....
Reviews.Author: Joy
Reviews.Content: Took the Fuji XP10 out twice; once camping at Lake Tahoe and again at Kern River. The Fuji functioned well on the first outting, but started developing problems on the latter camping trip: moisture started developing in the lens area, causing photos to appear foggy. The display became disrupted, as the moisture that permeated the camera began to make it's way through the housing.I sent the Fuji XP10 back to Fuji in hopes of getting it replaced, but received an invoice stating, "Water damage in camera not covered under warranty."Um, no kidding.The invoice also requested a payment of approximately $118 for an exchange of the same camera, with $100 of the cost going towards "labor"... Labor for what?!?! That's like buying a new XP10 with a little over a $20 discount over what I paid originally!What's the point of marketing a "waterproof" camera, when it's not really waterproof and Fuji won't even honor the warranty to make things right? It would serve Fuji well to learn from other companies that unconditionally back the products that they sell, like Pelican Products and Strider Knives. Don't claim your product is waterproof, freezeproof, dustproof, and shockproof, unless you can back your product under warranty. I'm going to pass on Fuji's offer to exchange my camera for the $118 fee, which I can use towards an Olympus Tough camera! ;-)As clean and compact as the Fuji XP10 appears, I will suggest to potential buyers of this camera to spend the extra money for the Olympus Tough series, which I am now considering. The Olympus Tough series may not be aesthetically pleasing as the Fuji XP10, but, like the AK-47 and Glock, the Olympus will probably work.Buy the Fuji XP10 at your own risk.

Reviews.Title: Waterproof:Yes;Good Pics: NO
Reviews.Author: Ed from Las Cruces
Reviews.Content: Just took the new camera on a white water rafting trip down the Grand Canyon. Clearly the camera met the specs for water tightness and shock ability as this type of trip had both. Pictures were of low quality, with little ability to handle a mix of shadows and light. Shutter is slow and unresponsive to the moment. In bright sunshine, or very low evening light, the lack of a view finder rendered most pictures a pure guess. Controls at the top of the camera for on/off and snapping the picture were too low a profile to allow for handling in tough situations. Worst of all was dismal battery life--only able to get about 100-125 pictures, while carefully turning the camera off in between, before battery was exhausted. Overall--very disappointing.

Reviews.Title: Surprisingly good little camera, with a couple of shortcomings
Reviews.Author: S. Greene
Reviews.Content: I got this camera to replace my previous underwater / shockproof Canon D10, which died after about 8 months for no apparent reason.  When I got the D10, it was the only low-cost point-and-shoot I could find for light underwater use, which made it good in its own way, but the electronics and sensor and etc. were already a couple of years out of date on the Canon, plus it was really big and bulky.I don't do serious underwater work, but do want a camera I can take out in the rain and occasionally in a swimming pool or to the beach, without worrying about it.  Also with small kids, the likelihood of a camera getting dropped is high, so a sturdy model is key.This little Fujifilm advertises the same kind of water- and shock-proof characteristics as the Canon, but it's a whole lot more modern in its features, and a whole lot smaller, which is great.  I haven't used it underwater yet, but for everyday use it takes good pictures.A few issues I have with it.  One, the cable connector is nonstandard.  It should be mini-USB, like so many other things - I keep a mini USB hanging off my computer anyway, and if I lose a mini USB cable it's easy to find another, vs. the Fuji cable which doesn't match anything else I own.Second, the mechanicals are not quite as polished as I'd like.  The waterproof cover for the cable connector doesn't seat well - it's very hard to get in.  And the battery cover has a strange hinge device that was confusing to figure out and I fear will not last well, since I have to open it frequently to extract the memory card, because the cable connector is nonstandard and hard to reseal.All in all I would still recommend this camera, and I hope these few flaws get corrected in a future model.

} } } Length:: 0:33 MinsThe Fujifilm Finepix XP10, newly available in April 2010, is a stylish little ultra-compact camera that invites you to have fun outdoors while taking pictures. It:- is waterproof to 10 ft. under water, perfect for swimming pools, beach, snorkeling (note: do not use in hot water!)- is shockproof up to 3 ft., great for jogging, cycling, or even letting your baby learn to take pictures- is freezeproof down to 14 degrees Fahrenheit (-10 Celsius)- is dustproof- is weatherproof except in very hot climates- has 12.2 effective megapixels- has 5x optical zoom and features a Fujinon lens for great clarity; lens focal length is 36-180mm in 35mm film camera terms- takes 720p widescreen, VGA or QVGA video- can zoom optically in video mode (but see note on audio recording below)- is really small and weighs just a little over 5 oz. with battery and SDHC card- uses SDHC memory card, no more xD that was championed by Fuji and OlympusI bought a green XP10 because I love spending time in the water -- and the green body looks really nice (and works whether you are a guy or gal)! I find that, outdoors during the day, the XP10 takes pictures with excellent clarity and excellent color saturation and contrast. Using fill-in flash in daylight truly enhances the picture. Indoors, because the XP10 lacks Fuji's legendary SuperCCD technology, picture quality is average for a compact or super-compact camera. It does have two natural-scene modes where it boosts the ISO (light sensitivity of the image sensor) at the expense of increased noise. I bought my XP10 to be used outdoors, in the pool and at the beach, so I haven't taken many indoor pics.Video shooting at 720p yields smooth, clear HD video clips. BTW, video size is limited only by the 2GB FAT32 file size limit -- this means even if you pop in a 16GB SDHC card, the longest video clip can only go up to 2GB in file size, due to the limit imposed by the FAT32 file system. Video is recorded as motion JPEG in an AVI container, so it can be played on many, many devices, at the expense of slightly larger file sizes than a more compact format like MPEG-2 or MPEG-4.While you can zoom optically -- a feature that every digital camera should have -- audio recording's volume level is lowered during zooming. Instead, the camera picks up some noise from the lens mechanism and that noise overwhelms the ambient sounds you want to record, which can be annoying when played back on a large TV. My advise is to use zooming sparingly during video mode. If you want great video recording on a compact digital camera, you should get a Sony or Canon or Panasonic camera (be prepared to pay a lot more for the waterproof feature, though).Battery life is on the short side, rated at 165 shots per charge with flash on 50% of the time. This is not surprising given the ultra-compact form factor. It's not an issue for me because I only use it at the pool (i.e., I have other cameras for other occasions); but if you plan to take it on a day trip to the beach, a spare battery is a probably a must, especially if you use the flash a lot or take a lot of HD video. BTW, regardless of the digital camera you buy, I think a spare battery is pretty much always a necessity. Fuji deserves kudos for including a very compact 100-240V wall charger.Anyway, my sample video clip shows how the camera works under water. The video resolution was set to QVGA (320x240) for easy upload to Amazon, but you should be able to see the amazing clarity both in and out of water (allowing for artifacts introduced by Amazon's video compression).In summary, the XP10 is a great waterproof, shockproof camera that every water enthusiast should bring along to record fun memories.

Reviews.Title: NOT Waterproof
Reviews.Author: T. Ingalls
Reviews.Content: I bought this camera for the waterproof feature, for beach and snorkeling photos. I took it to the beach and within 30 minutes it broke. The camera was never more than 2 feet underwater and it never hit anything. Water began leaking in the back display screen and the camera stopped functioning. Water also got in the front lens area and battery. Fortunately I was able to get the photos I had taken off the memory card.Picture quality was really nice and the display screen size is large for easy viewing. But if you plan on taking it in the water I suggest buying a different camera.

Reviews.Title: great service on my current vacation
Reviews.Author: hard worker
Reviews.Content: just bought this camera and am currently using it on my mexico vacation. the pictures are incredible. the auto setting is working fine. have tried out the low light and landscape mode and they work as advertised. i find getting the latest cameras every 2 years makes a huge difference in the image quality and features. this is a vastly better camera to use than my old sony w 170. the waterproof features a working fine so far. took the camera into the carribean sea for the past 4 days and have no problems so far. the various preprogrammed settings are doing their jobs as advertised. i use it primarily for my memories and pix log for my own use. i do not have a "pro's" perspective on image quality. for my use it has exceeded my expections. the movie mode a working to my satisfaction. i got some great video of the fort lauderdale-miami beach front from the sky from my airplane seat. the zoom function works with video too.  that will be a great memory. what . took the camera over  feet deep on a sea trek adventure and it did not have any problems. took the camera for a one hour snorkel adventure in my board shorts by mistake and did not have any problems with the camera. hope this is a useful review for the vast majority of the point and shoot crowd, for the rest there is always a slr, will try to post images in different settings when i get home, the hotel wifi does not let me upload pictures

Reviews.Title: Love, love this camera!
Reviews.Author: Melissa Kissell "ekiss3"

logTag.type = "text/javascript"; logTag.src = "/gp/customer-media/du/log.html?ie=UTF8&p=CustomerImage&s=CustomerVideoPlay"; head[0].appendChild(logTag); } if (cv_mo24S3PV7EV90PVcurrentClick) { return cv_mo24S3PV7EV90PVcurrentClick(); } } } Length:: 0:13 MinsSeems like several people aren't happy with this camera. I was showing my husband the reviews on here and we were really surprised by how many are disappointed with their camera. Maybe I don't expect enough however, I did drop it and it didn't break; it took great pictures in and out of the water and the video works nicely as well.I bought this for $139 at a local warehouse club and I think it's worth every penny for the underwater pictures and video alone. We've had a blast using it!BTW, the video image isn't grainy. Their are water sprinklers that shoot over the pool, so what you are seeing is sprinkles and not a bad video. I uploaded this video to FB and for whatever reason the FB looks clear while the same video on Amazon looks pixelated. Go figure.

Reviews.Title: Great, fun camera!
Reviews.Author: Kent Wheeler
Reviews.Content: Pros:Great outdoor pics!Great under water!ToughSR Auto works wellIndoor pics are fine for parties720p HD video!12mp!!5X optical zoomCons:Battery life!!!Software kind of sucksNot crisp indoor/lowlight pics  (please read more about this below - it's not so bad)So I got this camera as soon as it came out. This is my first camera actually. I never bought one before bc anytime that I want a camera I am at the beach, river, fishing, pool, drinking, etc (i live in FL). I couldn't bring myself to buy a camera that i know would break with my lifestyle. I liked the D10 but it's so expensive and I'm not gonna carry that egg thing in my pocket. The previous WP Fuji camera got pretty good reviews and I liked the sample pics people uploaded from them the most. Even more than the Olympus or Pentax. The new XP10 was about to come out with better resolution etc so I pre-ordered it.I am very happy with this camera! It looks real nice (silver), fits in my pocket, is super tough (i've thrown it around), the waterproof is great, 5X opt zoom (great for video), HD video, and the pics look real good for my purposes. I wasn't sure about the buttons behind rubber(?) before but they click when you press them so it's nice.I'm not a pro photographer, i'm not making posters of landscapes or anything. These pics are for facebook basically. I wouldn't have any pics at all if it weren't for a tough waterproof camera. My sister's SLR takes much better pictures indoors of my aquarium and food (we like to take pics of food we make).  But this is still an awesome camera.The battery does suck on this camera. It will only last for one day of fun. The next day it will die pretty quick if you try to keep going on it. So i'm gonna have to buy another battery or hope for an extended life one to come out  :/  I've used friends' cameras that last weeks on a charge. But, they're not WP.  I'll deal.The other thing - low light pics.  They don't come out crisp at all. It's not a big deal to me bc it's usually at parties when i'm drunk so it kind of captures the moment being a little warm and blurry looking. People actually seem to kind of like it. But just a warning.Overall this is a great camera for most every situation and is a good deal at $200 (mine came with a 4gb memory card).  I highly recommend  :]I can't wait to try it on my next ski trip!I will upload sample pics.UPDATE: The camera is still awesome. I took it snorkeling off Key Biscyane National Park. The camera held up great and the HD video of the reef is pretty cool. We went down further than 10ft a bunch of times but only briefly. That was a few months ago and the camera is still running great.One problem: the film that gives the rubber over the buttons that matte look is peeling off. I think it's from the chlorine in the pool. I peeled it all off and it's fine now. But just a heads up.I think the price is down to $140 w/memory card at Costco (awesome return policy). Can't beat that with a stick! My aunt went and bought one.I'll upload some new pics.

Reviews.Title: Don't buy!
Reviews.Author: Steve
Reviews.Content: Worst camera I have ever owned!  The size, shape and waterproof features are great, but the picture quality is HORRIBLE!  90% of all pictures are blurry, low light quality very poor and time delay on focus is so long that you will miss every one of your shots.

Reviews.Title: Not just for under water photos..
Reviews.Author: Amer
Reviews.Content: I needed a water proof camera for Warrior Dash next weekend. I was going to buy $10 disposable camera but since I was in the market for P&S; camera anyways, I decided to check it out. I played with it in the store, it seemed to do everything as well as any other P&S; camera. So I got this instead. (I got green one from Target)It is not very big, in fact, it is perfect size for me. Any smaller it would be uncomfortable in my large hands.Photo quality is pretty good. I also got Canon Rebel XSi, I could not easily tell the difference between photos taken with these two cameras.I took some photos under running tap water, it took the photos but it had hard time focusing correctly. Perhaps it will work better when fully submerged.Love the group or couple shot mode. It is like timer mode but instead of setting time, you tell it to take a photo of 1-5 people. And then it takes the photo when it detects that many still faces in the view.A few things that annoy me are the some weird USB cable, some of the button on back are not easy to press & I wish in movie mode you could  use shutter button to start recording stop instead of separate button. Battery life seems short too. Only 200 photos!!

Reviews.Title: One use and done! :-(
Reviews.Author: Jeffrey Fair
Reviews.Content: I used the camera once with nice results. Then took it to Hawaii for some snorkeling fun! Ha! My mistake. Wouldn't even turn on. I tried lots of things and nothing helped. Am trying to return it, but I won't have those images of turtles, dolphins, fish, etc...

Reviews.Title: Good (at least for my life)
Reviews.Author: JT
Reviews.Content: The reality of my life is that the other members of my family unit consist of two hyper little kids and a clumsy wife.  I learned many cameras ago that my cameras MUST be water/drool-proof, shock-proof, nag-proof, and any other proofs they can come up with.  Yes, I might sacrifice some picture quality or credit card slim size for my requirements but what good are those other cameras (like a few of my old ones) if they are "accidentally" broken within one month?My other digital camera is an Olympus Stylus Weather/Shock that is a few years old.  I must say that so far after a month's usage I prefer the Fuji XP10 over my other camera.What I like about the Fuji: -Good size and form factor.  Thumbs up to the large display screen. -I like that it takes a standard memory card (which was included).  My Olympus takes strange size memory card (=expensive, hard to find). -Easy to use (point and shoot).  Picture quality seems decent enough though not as good as some of the high end cameras -Did I mention it is weatherproof and shockproof?  Hasn't broken yet.  I do give my other Olympus camera a thumbs up for surviving several years. -Value for the price.What could be better: -Battery life hasn't seemed that great to me as of yet, but does come with a charger.  Battery life still better than my Olympus though. -Battery hatch hard to open.  I consider myself fairly good with gadgets but I actually had to read the instructions to figure out how to open the battery hatch = there will be questions/complaints/nags about this from my wife & kids.In summary, this camera fulfills my mandatory requirement of weatherproof/shockproof.  Second most important to me is size/wearability and this camera is good in that area.  Decent pictures are expected as a given and delivered by this camera.  Price for what you get is a good value.  = 5 stars by me (so far).  Will it survive the perils of life with my family?...only time will tell...if it breaks within one year I will add an update to this review.

Reviews.Title: Perfect for Summer Fun!
Reviews.Author: Colorado
Reviews.Content: I purchased this camera to take pics of our 18 month old who loves the water. We have an DSLR and a very nice point and shoot but I worry about taking those cameras on the boat or to the pool. The first day we had it my wife dropped it on the sidewalk getting out of the car, no problem. This past weekend we took it out on the boat, I used it in and around the water, works better than expected. Only problem we found was we got sun tan lotion on the front blurring the images, easily fixed with a towel....I even took a quick video of my daugher jumping in the water, video quality is better than our Flip video. Can't wait to take it along when we go hiking in the mountains.I would recommend this camera to anyone who already has a nice digital camera, if it is going to be your only camera you might want to look at the Panasonic.Pros:Worry free (only cost $150)WaterproofRuggedCons:No lens coverDoesn't float (use wrist strap)

Reviews.Title: Waste of money
Reviews.Author: ratlenhum "ratlenhum"
Reviews.Content: We got the Fuji XP10 and loved it at first. My husband opened it on Father's Day. By July 15th the flash stopped working. At the end of July, right before our Disney trip, water got in the lens. I left it for 2 days in a bag of rise to draw the moisture out so we could use it on our trip. 6 days into our trip we got a "zoom error" message and the camera was not functional. Mailed it off and of course all those problems are not covered by warranty and they want $[...] to fix it.Off to buy a new camera. I am not paying them to fix their piece of crap

Reviews.Title: Poor contrast, high noise, bad design, awful product
Reviews.Author: M. Mostov
Reviews.Content: The photos produced by this camera have unusually poor contrast and unusually high noise level, even at low ISO.  I took this camera on a trip where my friend was shooting pretty much same scenery with Canon SD800 under the same lighting conditions, yet the difference in quality is striking, almost every photo I took with XP10 went straight to trashcan.  BTW, I am quite experienced with digital photography, over the last 10 years owned 5 P&S; and 3 SLRs - I know how to use cameras and what to expect from them.The picture quality, IMO, is enough to strike this camera off anybody's wishlist, yet this doesn't end the list of problems:1) Camera has exceptionally long shutter lag.  I don't know how to measure it precisely, but it seems like a whole second, maybe more, passes after you press the button and before camera finally snaps a photo.2) LCD monitor is impossible to use on the sunny day - it's a nearly perfect mirror, as you try to compose the photo all you can see is the reflection of your own frustrated face.3) Buttons are poorly placed - as you hold the camera, the palm of your hand is pressing against super-sensitive control buttons and as you press the shutter, it's the other buttons that get inadvertently pressed - instead of taking a photo, camera switches to a different mode.4) waterproof - didn't test it personally, but beware: the manual states that to maintain waterproofness you are supposed to replace rubber parts every year or so.  This sounds like too much hassle and additional expense.  I used to own Pentax waterproof P&S; in the past - it was maintenance-free.5) The lens is uncovered - for a camera that supposedly designed to withstand abuse, this is a risky design decision.  I'd think that uncovered lens would get scratched soon.6) The video quality turned out to be as bad as picture quality if not worse.  When trying to shoot a clip in low-light conditions I got back basically a black screen.

Reviews.Title: XP10 not perfect but great starter for wet activities
Reviews.Author: Chris Zee Shutterbug
Reviews.Content: Fuji XP10 Solidly build underwater camera suitable for everydayI have used the XP10 for several weeks now. I first looked at its predecessor the WP30 several months ago for a trip to Crystal River for snorkeling with the manatees. It is perfect for that as the shallow water does not really require a pro type camera. At that time a friend loaned me his Olympus water resistant camera which worked out great. Except for the fact that I managed to corrupt his XD memory card and had to buy him a new one. All I did was to erase the pictures I took in a card reader rather than the camera. Thankfully everyone is going away from the proprietary memory stick and XD card formats towards SD only cards.Anyway, the Fuji compares very well with the almost twice as expensive Olympus by my own experience. It also competes against a Casio EXG1, Kodak, Pentax, Canon D10, Olympus Tough 3000/8000 and a Panasonic TS1/TS2 12 megapixel class  water resistant type cameras. Water resistant/proof here refers to cameras that can be submerged at a depth of 10-33ft for extended (but not indefinite, typically one hour in the specs) periods of time.I never intended it to be my primary camera, but decided to compare it to my past ones anyway. These were a 4mp 4x Canon A520, and a 5mp 12x Panasonic FZ20. My initial guess was that the 5x 12mp Fuji and the 12x 5mp Panasonic would give exactly the same amount of detail (5*12=60) when zoomed in far away and cropped to the same size. Nope, not even close. The Panasonic with a superb Leica lens was much much much better. As a matter of fact the Fuji was barely better in the amount of detail and PQ (picture quality) it provided than the older Canon. It really seems that when the pictures are examined up close (pixel peeping), the Fuji tends to smear fine details like blades of grass. This is not objectionable at normal viewing. Focusing is accurate and average in speed. Shot to shot times are about 2-3 sec, faster than the Canon, slower than the Panasonic.Some other brief observations: Any ISO above 200 is extremely noisy, when I thought the auto ISO function would take it above 200, I manually fixed the ISO at 200. There is image stabilization, digital, but I for the world could not see any effect, and you have to turn it ON as it is OFF by default. For me the face recognition only worked about 20% of the time when there were faces in the picture. The build quality of the camera is excellent, the metal body feels rock solid, and like many Apple products, it just feels good in your hand. The rounded corners allow it to slip very easily into a pocket. The control pad is too small for fingers and you have to use your fingernails. The data connector is yet another proprietary style plug. Ditch it and get a card reader instead, the software it comes with is not worth bothering with, if you do not have anything else, use Picassa (free). The HD movie quality is very good when you have ample light, indoors it is too grainy. Although zoom is available when filming, don't use it, the noise it makes on the file is overwhelming. Camera is NOT compatible with the EyeFi Pro X2 wireless SD cards (pictures store just fine, but any camera  playback read operation will corrupt the data). Battery life was reported as below average (<200 shots), which has not been my observation, but I picked up several spare widely available discount non OEM batteries here on Amazon.Overall I had very mixed feelings, as I expected more in terms of a 12mp picture quality and would have given the camera only 2 stars. Then I had to remember why I got it in the first place. It was for the weatherproof capabilities. Any picture that you can actually take is much better than the one you wished for but could not take for lack of equipment. So for the price, build quality, and convenience factor it gets 3 stars overall. It will probably be coming with me more often than not as a backup. You can spend twice as much and still not get a camera that will be good at all the things that I had issues with. (Questions welcomed)

Reviews.Title: Great little camera!
Reviews.Author: Jeffrey Pittman "Jeff"
Reviews.Content: This replaces a Canon pocket camera that I liked a lot, and an early model Flip video camera that was also a lot of fun and ridiculously easy to use.  The Canon would capture digital video, but not without my having to find and dig through the manual before trying.  This Fuji is as easy to use for video as it is for stills.  More on that later.I was a little disconcerted that there was no automatic lens cap, but what appears to be the lens is a thick glass (maybe acrylic?) cover that you can smudge to your heart's content, then grab your t-shirt and clean it as you would your spectacles.  Lens movement (zooming) happens inside the protective glass cocoon.  The large and bright display on the back has a durable, sturdy feel like the lens cover.  You get the feeling you would have to really try to scratch or damage them.Shooting still photos:  the camera starts up in "Scene Recognition" mode which works amazingly well at figuring out what you're shooting and setting the camera accordingly.  There are lots of other modes (presets, really) that are easy to select, like Beach, Snow, Landscapes, Night, Sport, Underwater and others that you see on a lot of cameras.  There are also some interesting oddballs like the setting that takes two pictures back to back, one with flash and one without, so you can choose the one you like best.  A terrific feature for me is Image Stabilization, which reduces the effect of shaky hands on photo quality.  I inherited something called "essential tremor" from my Mom's side of the family and my hands shake - sometimes not at all, sometimes a little, sometimes a little more.  The last set of photos I took with my old Canon was at a classic car auction and I had to discard more than half of them because of this.  In my experimenting with the Fuji (even at much higher resolution), photos are very, very sharp.Shooting video: I think I mentioned it's very easy compared to a still camera where video seems to be implemented as an add-on, not a primary feature.  You can choose from three quality levels, the higher quality consuming more SD card space than lower quality as you'd imagine.  Videos are saved as .AVI files.  One of the problems I discovered a while back was that videos easily become huge and may be difficult to upload to a website like YouTube, which has both size and duration (play length) limits.  The Flip video camera excels at making small, ready-to-upload videos and the Fuji doesn't do that (I don't think any still camera does that).  However, Google around for "HandBrake" for an open-source converter that will convert videos from one format to another and even allow you to specify how big the resulting video file will be.  Finally, I'm not sure, but it looks to me like the Image Stablization feature also works in video mode.  I just shot a "before" video of my kitchen prior to a major remodel, and what I saw in the camera display was shaky.  What I saw in the finished video file looked just fine.Cons that I probably wouldn't have noticed except for reviews on other sites:- no viewfinder.  Some like to hold the camera to their eyes to stabilize it.  The digital image stabilization features keeps this from being a problem for me.- can't zoom in/out while making a video.  You have to adjust the zoom where you want it before you start shooting.- took me a while to figure out how to open the battery + SD card cover.  You have to move the latch and slide the cover away from the camera body in one motion.Pros:- very easy to use for stills AND video.  This is a camera you can give Mom or Dad and they'll have success with it just using the defaults.- image stabilization.  This is my first camera with this capability and it is awesome.- lots of options for camera buffs who like to tweak settings; for those of us who don't care they are not in the way- 4GB SD card included (a surprise)- smaller than I expectedI'm looking forward to a long relationship with this thing.  Very nice piece of work!Update 6/11/2010: watch your battery level (I'm not sure exactly how to do that; it's on my list to find out) before downloading to the included desktop software (MyFinePix Studio).  I was copying a video from the camera to MyFinePix Studio and I'm thinking the battery reached critical level, and MyFinePixStudio stopped responding.  I thought I had lost the video (it had disappeared from the camera) but after recharging the battery and doing another sync, there it was.When the battery went, it went immediately.  An amber light had been blinking on the front of the camera just beforehand, which I thought just meant "busy," but now I'm thinking I was wrong.  Another reviewer criticized the battery life and I've had no problem with it lasting for a typical day, but now I think you do need to get a spare if you plan to be away from the charger for a few days.Still liking this camera and wouldn't change the 5-star opinion.  This is personality learning-curve stuff from my POV.

Reviews.Title: Nice Camera.... But, not durable
Reviews.Author: Justin
Reviews.Content: Got the camera at Costco for a deal because I had a coupon for some extra savings and I was going to the Virgin Islands, and really wanted to use the under water feature. I got the camera about 1 week before going on vacation and started taking pictures of my dog and what not, and while uploading the pictures to my computer, I noticed a small white dot on each one. This was a "bad" pixel. I tested it several times after that and still noticed that white pixel was still on the pictures, so I then took it back and exchanged it for another one (a Black one) because these things happen sometimes, not really a big deal.So I tested the second camera before going to the Virgin Islands, and it worked great, so off I went. -- Used the camera under water and took some awesome pictures. Did this for about 4 days, and noticed something very strange and frustrating... I could not turn on the camera anymore by holding down the power button. I took out the battery and placed it back in, and then it turned on, but I could not turn off the camera. Thinking I got sand down in there or something, I washed it out with warm running watter (remember it is water proof) and this help some what, but still, I had to hold the power button for a longer period of time and sometimes had to press it several times before it would turn on and off.I pretty much dealt with this the last 2 days of my trip and really like the pictures, but this was the second time I had technical problem with the camera that I could not fix. -- Call support and they sucked, they just referred me to the troubleshooting and really did not listen to my problem. The troubleshooting steps were very basic steps that I actually already complete (battery recharging, taking the battery out, etc.), but I have decided to take the camera back and get a different one.I liked the pictures and the underwater features, but I have 2 problems with the camera that almost makes it not worth getting, so I will be getting a different brand all together. Hope this helps someone in the future on making a decision.

Reviews.Title: Nice Camera For Its Purpose
Reviews.Author: Rob Reinhardt "Licensed Professional Counselo...
Reviews.Content: Note that this review is based on about three weeks of use.  We specifically purchased this camera because of an impending trip to the beach with our twins (their first experience of the ocean).  We also knew that we wanted something between our DROID phone cameras and our higher end DLR camera that was portable, small, took decent pictures (without the lag of the DROID camera) and even some short video while being difficult to damage.We put the camera through its paces at the beach and were very pleased with the results.  The picture quality and options for different camera modes are great.  I was especially pleased to find that it could take sequential shots. I have big hands so I'm sometimes leary of smaller cameras, but this fit well and I was able to take pictures and video while holding the camera in many different ways.  The camera was exposed to sun, sand, salt water and pool water at depths of up to five feet multiple times and continued to perform as expected.  Overall, the video quality was actually a bit better than I expected (I had very low expectations for video quality from such a device).  The following issues/items are what contributed to me giving this 4 stars instead of five:- As others have indicated, the camera has a short battery life.- Getting pictures to the computer was easier to do by ejecting the SD card and inserting it into the computer rather than carting around the specialty cable the camera requires.  As others have mentioned, a standard cable would be preferred.- You have to be very diligent about paying attention to the focus, especially when taking video.  Once you start shooting video, you can no longer adjust the focus and it can be very finicky about getting the focus correct.- The focus is sometimes finicky with photos as well, especially indoors in less than bright light- The LCD screen was scratched the first day.  I was as careful as I could to keep sand off of it and to rinse it when it did get sand on it.  I suppose it may be impossible to have an LCD screen intended for this kind of use that will not get scratched.- This isn't so much a flaw with the camera as a caveat to any who may be newer to waterproof cameras like we are.  It's important to be sure the lens is free of water when shooting.  Several of our shots have large obvious water droplets ruining the shot while there was no indication of this while shooting.  This is noted in the users manual.All in all, we are very pleased with the camera and hope to get lengthy use from it.

Reviews.Title: Great in the right situation
Reviews.Author: C. G. King
Reviews.Content: This little camera is geared to active, fast moving folks who want to preserve and share their fun, but who might be too rough on the standard camera.  This camera won't complain if dropped in the snow or splashed at the beach (I actually poured water over it as a test).  It's perfect for your budding photographer's school project as it can survive bumpy rides in backpacks and the occasional `Woops!'It's not the perfect camera for everyone, but it's pretty good.  You have to weigh your needs against its features.On the good side:  It's small and easily transportable.  The viewing window is really big and easy to see. It doesn't need a case and has a convenient wrist strap.  It's very automatic and readjusts itself fast and effectively to the situation at hand.  You can get really close to a subject and still get a clear picture and it does a great job with videos.  In fact, that's my favorite feature.  This little camera does an excellent job of keeping the focus good during videos so you can extract single frames as still photos with the proper software.  There is a separate video button to start and stop the recording so you don't end up framing the perfect still only to realize too late you forgot to reset some dial back to still after taking a video.  It doesn't seem to pick up sound as well as my other camera, however. You can zoom in before starting a video to get closer to the action, but you can't change the zoom during the video.The on/off button is illuminated so there's no question of the camera being on and there is almost no delay when taking a picture in bright light.  The zoom is pretty decent, going up to 5x and still taking a good picture in bright light.On the down side, there are some things I wasn't as happy with.  I had more trouble with the original setup than I expected.  It took me a while to get the hang of how things worked (the instructions aren't that great).  Once I did though, I was satisfied with the various menu options and editing ability.The battery, the card (they include a 4GB one) and the cable attachment spot are all in the same compartment and I still have trouble getting it open.  I need both hands and find the required combination of movements awkward. While the menu button and wheel on the back are fine, I don't always get prompt action from the other buttons.  It could be partly because I'm left-handed and am pushing them at a slightly different angle but I often have to retry several times before they respond.  The on/off button and shutter button are a little quirky for me too.  The W and T labels regarding zoom didn't mean anything to me so I looked them up on the internet and now know they stand for Wide Angle and Telephoto, but I'd have been a lot happier with Zoom In and Out.In a shady or flash situation there is a noticeable delay before the shutter snaps, which can lead to missing your shot, plus the quality of the picture isn't nearly as good as in bright light.  I've fiddled a little with settings but haven't gotten that to improve.  That, of course, isn't a problem if most of your use will be on the slopes or the beach.Today I took almost 100 stills and videos and reviewed them several times, and worked with the menu options and choices much more than you usually would, but in the course of all that I managed to use up the entire battery life and had to recharge it again.  The recharge took about an hour.  I will grant you my use was excessive, but still I was surprised that I could run the battery out in one day since my other camera batteries seem to last forever.  Clearly all the automatic refocusing and switching options are resource heavy activities.  You can even hear the gears working in there.  If you want the automation (which is very useful) working for you all the time and expect to be taking lots of pictures, it would probably be wise to have an extra battery on hand.I only use the software to extract the pictures from the camera and at first was stymied about starting that operation, but found in the instruction book that I had to turn the camera on via the review button rather than the on button.  Then the software starts automatically and is effective for picture extraction.  The included USB cable is not very long, which is good for a laptop or front USB port, but not so good if you want to hook it up in the back of a desktop computer.  The separate battery recharging unit which plugs into the wall has folding prongs which make it somewhat easier to carry with you on trips. It's lightweight, but a bit bulkier than it needs to be.Bottom line: this seems like a good rugged little camera that will please lots of people who want to use it while vacationing and doing active things, but because of the low light issues, this may not be right as an `only' camera.

Reviews.Title: Inexpensive; too bad it didn't last long
Reviews.Author: dappy15
Reviews.Content: This camera was a cheap alternative to the higher priced cameras of its class. I read through reviews and saw both pretty good ones and saw some really bad ones as well. I didn't want to spend too much so I decided to go with it and give it a try. I consider it more of a "fun" camera. If your expectations for it is not sky high, you won't set yourself up for an easy disspointment. The picture quality on this camera can't compare to my old Canon point and shoot. Since I bought the camera mainly for water activities, I'll focus more on this.Water video was interesting but not really good. It doesn't have image stabilization and if you're like most people, you're probably trying to have fun and video above the water or while snorkeling than to try to keep your hands as steady as possible. The 720p resolution on it is nice to have. I'm sure it would take nice videos if you're using a tripod. I found that most of my videos were annoying to watch because it looked like I was filming when an earthquake is happening. The sound when taken on land was sometimes muffled and I can't understand anything. Maybe defective for this camera? I don't know.The underwater picture quality was not too bad. It was much better than those disposable underwater cameras. I don't really have any comparison for quality besides that. If it worked, it's cool enough for me. When the camera was out of the water and wet, you can see the water spots on the lense when viewing your pictures later. One drop of water may be small but when enlarged to a computer screen, it's a good portion of your picture. Maybe I needed to wipe rain-x on it so the water dropplets won't stick on the lense. =)The problem comes when it only lasted a short while. On my 2nd outing using the camera at the beach in the water, it started acting funny and stopped working. I dried it off and was hoping what I read from other reviewers did not just happen to me. I opened the battery compartment and found that sand and water managed to get in. How much, I don't know but enough for it to stop functioning. The memory stick wasn't demaged when I dried it off and put it in the pc, so there's a plus there. Probably just enough water to shock it. There goes my hopes that it would not happen to me.I had exchanged it for another one but I'm a little hesitant using it now.

Reviews.Title: Great Camera
Reviews.Author: Jinelle Garcia "Online Shopaholic"
Reviews.Content: This is a great camera. It is water resistant and it's really great for teenagers and if you're going on vacations. It takes clear pictures too not really blurry ones. It fits perfectly in my hand and the buttons are easy to press. It is very easy to get used to. :) I love it and it's my new favorite thing. People keep complaining about the camera, if you've had a sorta professional camera or more expensive camera before of course it's going to be different and not what you expected. You get what you pay for but in this case you get a little more than what you paid for. It is such a good camera. It does take a while to start up sometimes which may make you think that it's broken but just press and hold the power key and it will be okay. The only thing I have to say is to be extremely careful when you close the battery and SD compartment. Shut it tight or water can get into it.Update: I have had this camera for about 4 months already and it is still in perfect condition. It still takes pictures perfectly and nothing has gotten damaged. It still prevents water leakage and there is no sort of sign saying that its messing up. Goooddd Camera, great quality, great design, great pictures, just great overall.Update 2: 3 years later and camera still works great! Still water proof and still takes great pictures! I've dropped it more times than I can count (even on concrete) and it hasn't broken at all. Best camera I've ever owned.

Reviews.Title: Great camera
Reviews.Author: Mikehn
Reviews.Content: I took this camera to Orlando for a week and had it in my swim trunk pocket on just about every water ride at Typhoon Lagoon, Blizzard Beach, and Aquatica.  Dynamite little camera!  To top it off, I charged the battery before I left home and it lasted the entire week without a recharge.  I did not take any pictures underwater, so I cant comment on the quality of underwater photos.  However, this camera was perfect for snapping pictures of my little one while chasing him around Orlando's finest water parks.

Reviews.Title: Don't bother
Reviews.Author: pattara pathumarak
Reviews.Content: Pros:1. Takes great underwater photos.2. Reasonably priced.Cons:1. Out-of-water photos (indoor and outdoor) are TERRIBLE. Especially indoor photos, which turn out orange-ish regardless of how I adjust the settings. You really can only use this camera underwater. Don't bother in any other setting.2. Poor design/construction. The rubber around the buttons began to bubble and peel during our first snorkeling venture, after probably 15 minutes in the water. Now, after every water use, we find a bit of water in the lens. I fully expect the camera to simply fizz out from water exposure soon.Overall, I am not satisfied with the camera as it's started to deteriorate after only a few months and generally the quality of the photos are really poor. (We've started relying on our iPhone for photos in indoor/outdoor settings, as they turn out significantly better than photos with the XP10). The underwater photos are great, but the waterproofing seems to be more of a temporary feature and after minimal use you can expect it to deteriorate.Looks like I'll be in the market for a new camera soon and next time I won't be woo-ed by the "underwater" and "rugged" marketing claims. I'll simply buy an underwater case.

Reviews.Title: Great little durable camera!
Reviews.Author: 3 Wee Bairns "3 Wee Bairns"
Reviews.Content: I am replacing a Canon SD960IS which took great pictures, but twice was accidentally turned on while in my pocket - which caused a "lens error".  The lens would no longer fully retract nor would it focus, making the camera useless.  The first time the camera was under warranty and fixed by Canon at no charge.  This time the warranty had expired and would have cost $130 to repair...time for a new camera!I also have a Canon EOS Rebel and have always had Canons, even in the days of film - I love the quality of Canon pics.  However, when I found this Fuji Finepix XP I liked the fact that the lens is internal - and cannot have the same type of accident as my Canon PowerShot Elph.  I had no need for underwater photos - although, I'm sure I will use the function now that I have it.  But I do like the fact that the camera is waterproof and shockproof.  Having 5 children, I don't have to worry as much if one of them grabs the camera and I can take it to the beach, pool, waterpark without being a neurotic mess.  Also it is freezeproof, so if I have it in my car in winter in Buffalo, NY and happen to forget to bring it in...not a big deal!  Also it is a great size, very small and light - slips easily into a pocket without requiring a case because of its durability!I took video footage at a concert with this camera and thought it was good quality.  Picture quality is far better than I expected after reading other reviews.  The macros were impressive!  Daylight pics are great - low light photos are not bad, but not as good as Canon.  (See photo of dog above - it was shot at night in a dark room with very little light)All in all I am very happy with this camera and would definitely recommend it!

Reviews.Title: Good pictures, poor video
Reviews.Author: Kevin Delgadillo "Scotts Valley Cat"
Reviews.Content: Takes excellent photos on land and underwater. HD video was a key feature that attracted me to this product.Unfortunately, the video quality overall leaves a lot to be desired:- HD 1280x720 is encoded as 30fps MJPEG AVI (outdated format). HD video looks pretty good, but is not very smooth - it is jittery. Worst of all, the audio in the HD video contains very loud background noise -- a high-pitched sound combined with a strange low-end sound that resembles a heartbeat. It's more than a distraction, it makes the videos unwatchable IMO.- SD 640x480 also encoded MJPEG AVI. Video looks pretty good for this resolution. Suffers from same jittery video motion. Gone is the high-pitched sound, but the low-end background "heartbeat" sound is still there.If the video issues weren't there, this would be a perfect point-and-shoot underwater camera.Due to audio noise issues with the video, I'm returning this item.

Reviews.Title: Fujifilm FinePix XP10 camera
Reviews.Author: Terri "3kids-at-home"
Reviews.Content: This came in the mail yesterday, and I am having a ball with it. This package also came with a 4G SD card, ready to load. Comes with rechargable battery pack, and charger, cable for computer uploads, and strap. I charged the camera up, took about three hours to charge. It takes great photos, still, or action. We tested my son jumping off the coffee table, and it caught him in mid-air! It was cool. I also took several close up photos of people and flowers and it took very crisp pictures. This camera also has a feature to send photos directly to Facebook, or You Tube. Which is really cool. Has a sepia mode, and a mode to blur your selected people in your picture that you don't want to show in your Facebook, or You Tube down load. Nice feature! View your photos by a press of a button. You can do a slide show, or scrapbook mode to view your pictures right on the camera. Also, this camera takes videos too. No red eye either, cool. Drop proof, dust proof, shock proof, and water proof. Now if it could cook dinner, this would be all you need! Buy this camera, you won't be a bit sorry. I love it! Very easy to use, if I can use it, anyone can.

Reviews.Title: Fujifulm FinePix XP10
Reviews.Author: J. Glass
Reviews.Content: Camera was for my 10 year old granddaughter. I did a lot of research on what camera would suit her best. She has had several other cameras but they would break easily or were too childish for her. Although I felt the price might be too steep for a child's camera, getting her a ruggedized camera was the whole point of this and cameras with similar attributes cost at least two times what this one did. I decided to sacrifice picture quality since this was going to a child who probably would not be too picky if her pictures or video weren't perfect.So...she got the camera as a present for Christmas and after 30 minutes of instruction on the camera features and some photography fundamentals she was off and taking great photographs. She also figured out the video on her own and started filming everything she could think of.  Also, the smaller size of the camera fit perfectly in her hands and she took photos and videos all day long with the half-charged battery out of the box with no problems. Her camera outlasted two other cameras that were more expensive brand name ones!Bottom line-  very good camera for the money.  Not for pros but great for us "Joes". BTW, I thought I was sacrificing picture quality - not so. This camera takes some clear photos.

Reviews.Title: If you can wait, get something better!
Reviews.Author: M. Guzman
Reviews.Content: I just got this camera to try it before our Disney vacation.  I own an SLR, so as far as quality goes, there is obviously NO comparison.  However, and even expecting a so-so job, I am pretty disappointed with the quality of the images at 12MP, 1600ISO.  Tough to focus on small objects at a 3in. distance, you can hear the zoom rattle in there, trying to make sense of the image (tried it on Manual, Portrait, and a couple of other settings).  Long distance and regular shots, it does an OK job, for the $120 that I paid for it.The Video is horrid. Bad quality even in the HD setting, you can see a lot of pixelation.  When you zoom in and out, all you can hear is the zoom rattling and it cuts off sound if you are narrating anything.  It does OK against shake, but not worth it at all.  Unless you are willing to use it without the zoom capability, get something else.I haven't tried it under water because I'm going back this afternoon to return it, so I don't even want to bother with it!!I guess overall, and for the price paid, you could get away with using this as your 'water' vacation camera, but if you want nitid, better images, look for something else!

Reviews.Title: Not Worth it.
Reviews.Author: Kayak Guy
Reviews.Content: My old 3 megapixel camera takes better pictures than this! I like the size and ruggedness features but that's as far as it goes. Never used this underwater but it did fine in the rain until I tried taking a picture while it was wet. Any little bit of water on the lens results in weird looking dots all over the picture. About the only pictures that turned out mostly ok were the Macro pictures of flowers. Everything else came out grainy and fuzzy and with weird contrast. Video actually turned out better images than still pictures...that is until I used the zoom and it immediately went out of focus and you get an annoying buzzing noise on the video whenever zoom is used. I'm returning and going back to my larger but significantly better quality Canon.

Reviews.Title: This camera performs exactly to its specification
Reviews.Author: PhotoBuff
Reviews.Content: I read through most of the reviews when I decided to purchase this camera and unfortunately most of them did not help me and made me cautious about buying this camera. To help other folks decide I am writing this review based on heavy usage in this camera.First of all I picked the Green color in case I lose the camera in the water it is easier to see than the black or gray. I bought this camera to use it at the waterparks and the lakes we visit during the summer. This camera went with us to 3 different waterparks and 2 different lakes. I always had it in my swim trunks pocket regardless of what I was doing: swimming, building sand castle with the kids, playing in the water etc.Verdict: this camera performed exactly the way it is supposed to work, it was tight enough to disallow water or sand to go into the battery compartment. Picture quality was not the best however I did not expect a superb quality. But I was able to take pictures that I would not have able to take without it. sometimes you have to wipe the glass in front of the lens because a drop of water can ruin a picture. The camera was slow to focus (I played with all modes) but again waterparks I went to were mostly indoors (light conditions). Under water both the video and still were awesome, I took very nice shots of my kids going under water. Depending on shooting conditions, the pictures sometimes turn out to be grainy, but again this is a function of the ISO and the shutter speed to get the picture.Beware of the battery, the battery life is really short, I recommend you purchase a spare battery and have it on hand during the day because you will run out of batteries. Per trip I average about 200 pictures and videos, and I usually get about 80 pictures to print or keep. Keep in mind that a lot of shots are thrown out due to composition (which is a user error and not a camera error).Summary: If you are purchasing this camera to use it only at the beach/water you will be happy, but if you are planning to use it as a walk around camera you will be disappointed.

Reviews.Title: Great features, disappointing performance
Reviews.Author: Joshua V. Schneider
Reviews.Content: Starting with some basics about the use of the camera, I would say that the battery life was very good, and was a noticeable improvement over my previous digital camera which used AA's. There is no viewfinder, so you must use the LCD screen, but it doesn't drain the battery very quickly. The battery charger gave a full charge in about 1 hour.The LCD screen is large and easy to read. Underwater it was obviously more difficult to see, with glare and sunlight, but when there were objects in focus, such as fish or corals, it was very usable and showed good color. The challenge is that underwater photography is not as simple as one might first guess, because when you are trying to take pictures of fish, for example--you are moving, the water (including any suspended sand or sediment) is moving, and the fish is moving. So you expend lots of tries to get a few really good pictures. This was the camera's most interesting feature. Fortunately the Finepix XP10 really did perform, and we were able to get plenty of good pictures underwater, even under less than ideal conditions. Due to the visibility, we found that the zoom feature didn't work very well under water. Holding the camera with both hands at arm's length to get as close as possible to the object gave the best photo. One of the things that I didn't like was that it was very awkward to hold the camera with one hand and take pictures, especially underwater. The not-quite-rectangular shape of the camera made it slippery to hold with one hand. It's limited by a 10 ft. depth, so this camera is ideal for pictures while snorkeling, but not for deeper diving.The most disappointing thing about the Finepix camera was the use in typical, average lighting conditions. Inside with natural light coming in through windows, outdoors with a mix of sunny and shady lighting, and a variety of other normal, mixed lighting conditions, the pictures frequently came out overexposed in one region, and too dark in others. I experimented in many different situations, always trying the auto, Scene recognition auto, natural light, landscape, party, etc settings. Sometimes I could get a little improvement by changing the settings, but who wants to have to take six pictures on different settings before you get one that comes out decently? Natural light seemed to work the best in most situations, but I found that the Scene Recognition and Auto settings tended to perform poorly. They weren't able to adjust well to produce natural color and lighting balance. Sometimes it would appear on the LCD that the image was caught well, but when you snapped a photo the colors were distorted, something was overexposed, or it was blurry. I also occasionally had some improvement by using program mode and lowering the ISO to 100 or 200, but sometimes these pictures came out a little blurry as well. One trick that sometimes helped in mixed lighting conditions was to aim the camera at a brighter region of the intended picture and half-click to focus, then move to the person or object that you wanted in center frame. This sometimes compensated for overexposure.The camera performed better in certain lighting situations, however. The nighttime setting captured shots that most digital cameras couldn't. Any moving objects were blurry, but a moonlit bay or the lights from a skyline came out better than I expected. In dusky conditions it was still difficult to get a good, balanced shot. Sunset photos probably performed the best for the camera, and both in landscape and sunset mode it was able to compensate well for having very bright and direct sunlight coming in, without overexposing the picture, strangely enough. Also, landscape mode worked well in bright, sunny conditions. I thought the video mode worked well, and adjusted well to different lighting, and could zoom in and out while filming, though this created a loud sound in the finished video.If you are mainly buying this for underwater use, it's a good buy. But overall I would say that the camera is good for certain special uses, but for a general purpose camera, I was disappointed.  You typically want a point-and-shoot camera that can automatically adjust to situations and capture the lighting and color accurately, but this camera did not perform well at that task. The underwater feature and the variety of modes were very useful and interesting. I didn't find the face detection mode to work very easily and usually turned that off. The feature for adjusting to camera shake didn't seem to work very well either. It seemed excessively sensitive. The camera has an impressive array of features, and is user-friendly, but I had difficulty getting many high-quality, crisp, well-colored shots.

Reviews.Title: Rugged, Small, Convient, great for the on the go family..no problems with battery life
Reviews.Author: JRay
Reviews.Content: Edited Update:  I just had to update the below review.  This is the best camera I have ever had in terms of getting water pictures.  I have had to much fun this summer with this camera.  How awesome to go to the waterpark and wade through the whole waterpark (especially the wave pool) with the camera available to take great action water soaked pictures.  I had this camera on my wrist and in the water for hours.  The battery did well and the camera was untouched by the water.  This won't be the last Fuji product I buy.  I would have never thought to get a waterproof camera, but I am SO glad to have this.  I have had so much fun reviewing this product, and using it!!! GET IT if you want to have fun!!I really love this camera.  It is small and very easy to take anywhere. It fits in any pocket or compartment that I have no matter how small.  I seem to be on the move constantly with my two boys 4 and 8, one minute we are headed to a  ball game or the city pool, or maybe waterpark.  So I am constantly changing bags and thowing contents here and there.  This camera doesn't have to worry about surviving my kids, but me and so far so good.  I have tossed it and dropped it.  So it has thus far proven to me its shock value.I really like the Zoom.  Last year my three year old was playing with my camera and wrecked my Zoom.  It was one of those that came out of the camera.  This zoom doesn't so I don't have to worry about that again, in case he gets his hands on it.  I also found the Zoom to be very adequate, and for the money it gives you more zoom that alot of cameras in this price range.The picture quality is wonderful.  I have though found that if your light quality is not that bright or great you may not get the pictures you want.  We went to the museum and the pictures didn't turn out that great, but the lighting there was horrible.  You can upload your pictures right to facebook which can be very convient.I found the controls to be easy to control.  You do have to press right on the W and T to get the Zoom to work, but I haven't had any problems doing that.  I have not had any problems getting used to opening the battery compartment like some other reviewers had.THe battery life for me has been just as good as my other cameras.  It seems to charge up fast, and the battery lasts all week for me while I am taking pictures everyday with it.  I have been pleased with it.Overall the camera is great for me. It meets my needs, and we all have different needs.  I love how durable it seems.  I have had no problems with dropping or tossing it in my bag, on the floor, or even in the water.  Yes, it is very nice to have that waterproofing on your camera!I would highly recommend this camera.  The last thing  I really liked on ths camera that  I have not seen as an option on any other camera, is how it will take two pictures of the same scene for you.  It will do it once with the flash and one without the flash.  You just have to make sure your subject stands still enough for the camera to get both pictures.  But I have really liked that setting.  Enjoy your summer and memories with this camera.

Reviews.Title: Just plain bad.
Reviews.Author: S. B.
Reviews.Content: I knew this was a low-end camera when I bought it, but my old waterproof Olympus died and I had a friend who swore by Fuji. I swore by (and at) this camera too when I started using it. The only nice thing about it is its size, and that the battery from my Olympus Stylus fit this camera so I could use the second battery when the Fuji battery died (which was regularly.) But its response time is extremely slow: turning on, focusing and processing. There is no indicator to show if the camera is in stand-by mode or off, so you have to either guess or press the power button and risk turning the camera off when it was actually only in stand-by, then wait for it to turn on again. The automatic scene settings are unreliable; once it is in macro, it tends to stay there even when pointed at a landscape. As far as I an tell there is no way to turn off the red-eye reduction. Underwater photos are hit-and-miss. Sometimes the photo will come out beautifully and sometimes it will just be grey, even with "underwater" mode manually selected. Water beads up on the lens, causing blurs in the photos. This never happened with my other underwater cameras. I even tried Rain-x on the lens covering as a last resort and it didn't help. From start to finish -- waiting for the camera to power up to looking at blurry photos or remembering missed shots -- using this camera was an exercise in frustration. I'm getting a Canon.

Reviews.Title: great camera at a great price
Reviews.Author: ryry321
Reviews.Content: I bought this camera for my vacation to the Bahamas and used it on several occasions before the trip at the beach. It takes excellent pictures and video. Very easy to use. I'm glad I got it for the trip being that its water proof on a cruise it made life so much easier for taking photos and not having to worry about getting it wet and ruining the camera. I took it every where with me and never missed a shot. Even just stored it in the cooler of beer several times being that its freeze proof as well. When compared to my friends $400 Olympus she had there was no difference in quality of photos only a few different features on hers than this one. Well worth the money!

Reviews.Title: For the price you can't go wrong! But you will need a 2nd camera if not using it underwater
Reviews.Author: R Gomez
Reviews.Content: I really wanted the new model that just came out, XP30 but it came out the same day I was leaving to my trip so I got this one for my underwater pictures, and for the price... YOU CAN'T GO WRONG! beautiful underwater pictures, great video too... BUT not great for any other type of pics I use my Sony DSC-W330 for that. Is it a hassle to have 2 cameras? Kind of, but it's not terrible either, but I would def wanted to check the new model to see the picture quality outside the water.Did it break like others say the first time I used it? NO... so I wonder if they were just not careful when closing the battery compartment. I also bought the XP10 accessory kit which is great.But I am telling you, for the price, you can't go wrong if you are ONLY using for underwater*** UPDATING MY ORIGINAL REVIEW ***The camera didn't last very long. I had to send it for repair twice. Now they don't even service it, they just give you the option to upgrade for $75. Does not very long if you use it underwater which was the purpose of buying this camera. It lasted about 3 trips

Reviews.Title: takes good underwater photos (until it died) but that's it
Reviews.Author: Chris Purcell
Reviews.Content: I bought this camera almost a year ago for kayaking and snorkeling trips.  It takes nice underwater pictures and pretty good above water pictures when you are in the water.  That's about it though, normal pictures often come out faded or hazy looking.  This is especially true in certain lighting conditions such as indoor pictures with light coming through a window, for example.  I compared pictures of the same landscape that this Fuji camera took with ones from a 10 year old 4MP Canon and the Canon's pictures blew it away.  The clarity was night and day.  Last week during my trip to the Dominican Republic I jumped in the water for my snorkeling trip and tried to turn the camera on only to realize that the camera had died.  Water leaked into this "waterproof" camera somehow!  You can see water under the view finder and the camera is officially dead now.  Luckily after letting my memory card sit out for a few hours to dry I was able to restore the pictures but the camera is dead.  It's too bad it died right before my swim with sharks as this was one of the reasons I bought it.Looking back at it, maybe one of the compartments on the camera was not fully closed when I brought it into the water.  Before I threw the camera into the garbage recently I noticed that the piece of rubber on the side was not fully closed.  Maybe it was like that when I jumped in and that's why it leaked.  Who knows, but I'm about to buy a new waterproof camera and I'm staying away from Fuji. I gave the camera 3 stars because it takes good underwater pictures and it's cheap.  I'll give them the benefit of the doubt and assume that most of them will not leak and die like mine did.I just bought a Canon D10 to replace this which I should have done from the start.

Reviews.Title: Good for a fun camera
Reviews.Author: M. Hertzler
Reviews.Content: I am not a professional photographer. So all I am looking for is a quick, fun, point and shoot to take with me to the beach. My husband found this at Costco for a great price so we grabbed it and took it along to the beach.It was a great camera to have poolside, to capture silly shots of our kids, our pets and each other playing in the pool. My husband and daughter had a great time taking those "just plunged into the water" shots, although it took us about 5 minutes to get the timing right with the shutter.It never let us down as far as battery life, uploading photos to the computer, and ease of use. I will say that the viewing screen is useless in the sunshine, as we couldn't see if our shots were coming out or not.But all in all we are happy with our vacation photos!

Reviews.Title: Like it!
Reviews.Author: Joshua
Reviews.Content: I love this camera! It takes great pictures and is definetly durable I've already put it through some abuse and it works just fine. The only down fall to this camera is the amount of time it takes to snap a picture, if the speed was a second or two faster the camera would be perfect.

Reviews.Title: Yes, it's waterproof, but it has some serious bugs
Reviews.Author: Joe A "joe23409"
Reviews.Content: I just got back from a 2 week vacation in Africa, and this camera was 100% waterproof for me.  I gave it a good workout, taking it white water rafting on the Zambezi river (the toughest rapids in the world), as well as tubing, kayaking, and just plain old rain.  I dented the camera on the Zambezi, but it still works like new, and never took in any water.That's where the positives end though.  This camera has software bugs, and they're nasty.  In the automatic modes, the camera sometimes gets exposure and/or focus wrong.  I'm not talking about a picture that is a little dark or light or a slightly soft focus, this camera will randomly decide to turn the exposure all the way up or down and you end up with a framed blob of bright white or inky black.  Likewise with focus, I now have some very artsy abstracts in beiges and browns, that with any focus at all would have been beautiful snapshots of lions playing.Fortunately I found a solution -- exposure and focus seem to work fine in the landscape preset mode, and the portrait preset mode.  So it all worked fine as long as I had face recognition off and didn't use any of the fancy automatic preset modes.Other nits -- like many point and shoots today this camera has no viewfinder, bad news in sunlight.  To make it worse, the LCD dims after just a few seconds, making it even harder to see in sunlight, to get full brightness on the LCD you have to remember to press the shutter button halfway.  Also, there's a delay of about a half second from pressing the shutter button to when the picture is taken, making it hard to get the exact shot you want.  I also hate it's indoor white balance, much much too red, maybe it's another bug that I haven't found the solution to yet.So my overall rating is 4 stars -- mostly because it's a waterproof camera that really is waterproof, and as long as you know how to work around the bugs it works fine.PROS -- Really is waterproof.  Takes good pictures when in the landscape or portrait preset modeCONS -- Software bugs render automatic modes useless.  Has no viewfinder and LCD dims too quickly

Reviews.Title: bad quality pictures
Reviews.Author: kad9600
Reviews.Content: This camera does great when you are outdoors with perfect lighting. Besides that the quality is horrible. Any indoor picture taken or any picture taken at night is horrible. I thought I had some decent pictures on my vacation. They dont look bad on the little screen. But uploaded to the computer the quality is not so good. I deleted more pictures than I saved. Luckily we traveled with others and I have their photos as well. I have had 2 Canon powershot camera prior. I bought this camera for the fact it can go underwater and is "drop proof." I does take ok pics in the water. But if you have a drop of water on the lens then of course it show in the picture. So even if you are out on the water, but not in the water and moisture will ruin the picture. Just bought this and already want a canon again. Even if i have to go back to 10mp, it wouldnt matter. The pictures are so grainy, it might as well be a 3mp camera. I am no professional photographer but I do enjoy taking pictures and i am pretty familar with camera functions. Nothing I did could make pictures look good. EVERY picture had to be edited in some way and still they were terrible. Only buy if you want as a "pool camera" or "beach camera" would never use again as my only camera!!

Reviews.Title: works fine
Reviews.Author: Matt
Reviews.Content: Short version: The camera WORKS as intended underwater, with a decent picture, acceptable video.I was concerned about the other reviews, regarding leaking issues, etc.. but the price was right so who cares. The wife and I are planning a trip to Thailand in December and want a somewhat reliable underwater camera. Per the reviews, this is a risky move. So as soon as it arrived, charged the battery, then immediately threw it (yes, threw) into the bathtub whilst recording. Works fine, tried under running water, just peachy.So for the past couple months, we've been taking it to the property and using it in the swimming pool, it's only 4 feet deep but did put it through the same pressures (lots of throwing, etc). The buttons work fine under water, they're a bit small but so is the camera. With goggles or mask (duh), you can see the screen fine, and still managed to get through the sometimes slowly responding menus.This was mostly 720p video, and some still shots.The picture quality as far as still digital cameras go, is just OK. My 4 year old Canon Powershot takes far better still photos, of course it's not waterproof and that is really the point of this review. The features are mostly the same as any other camera. There is a fully automatic mode that works fairly well, as well as a face detection mode; in case you forget what a human face looks like.The video quality is fine for the price range, not stellar, but not terrible. It's not intended as a camcorder but works fine as one, the vids just have to be short. The microphone works fine when emerging out of the water and clears up quickly.
