The lens works great, water drops roll off most of the time.The battery/SD card compartment is sealed with a rubber gasket on the plastic door, not much to say just worth mentioning.Con: don't use the flash, it is worthless. You'll be able to take about 10 pictures before the battery dies, no that is not a joke. It was added as a courtesy, I assume. Depth is only 10ft anyway, should not be an issue.I will continue to beat up the camera, both above and underwater, and will definitely write if it ends up leaking.To sum it up, this so far makes a fine underwater video camera, above water still shots? Not so much.

Reviews.Title: great little waterproof camera!
Reviews.Author: RNB "mom & pop to 2"
Reviews.Content: As other reviews have stated, it's a great little camera, for what it's designed for, with a few minor drawbacks but they aren't enough to keep from purchasing it. We got ours about 6 weeks ago, but have used it almost daily so far this summer, in pools, waterparks, canoeing, at the stable where we ride horses, at the park....pretty much everywhere!! Our take on some of the features:waterproof - 100% yes, and amazing shots in/under the water.  No problems in the pool or at the waterpark, although I did notice this morning that some of the plastic coating around the keys seems to be peeling up this morning - not sure what is up with that but I'm not very happy about it...12MP pictures - for a point & shoot, takes excellent pictures.  Has underwater setting, sport setting, night setting etc, for even better pictures. Have not used video funtion to say how it works.Battery life - sucks, to be blunt.  We rarely get a full day out of the battery, a day and a half tops.  Although I do take a LOT of pictures.  Extra battery and/or car charger are an absolute necessity and need to be factored into overall cost.  One note - for some reason the camera WILL let you put the battery in UPSIDE DOWN!!!  Locks right into place too!  So if you replace the battery and it doesn't power on, try switching out the battery position.Physical attributes - small/compact, lightweight, huge display screen.  Battery/memory card door slot IS very hard to open, but once you figure it out it's not bad.  There is no viewfinder on the camera, if this bugs you (it does my husband) which is really only bad in situations like very bright light where you can't see the LCD very well.  Tons of settings, and very similar to other fuji cameras as well ( I have a fuji SLR with similar functions so I LOVED not having to re-learn all the settings)Overall, a great camera and we've really had fun using it.  For $150 an excellent buy, as long as it continues to hold up - only time will tell on that one...but plan to spend another $20 for extra battery/car charger.  We get stopped by people all the time asking about it at the waterpark & pool, and so far I have highly recommended it.  I'm a little concerned about the peeling around the key area, so I will keep an eye on that and update later.

Reviews.Title: Just plain bad.
Reviews.Author: S. B.
Reviews.Content: I knew this was a low-end camera when I bought it, but my old waterproof Olympus died and I had a friend who swore by Fuji. I swore by (and at) this camera too when I started using it. The only nice thing about it is its size, and that the battery from my Olympus Stylus fit this camera so I could use the second battery when the Fuji battery died (which was regularly.) But its response time is extremely slow: turning on, focusing and processing. There is no indicator to show if the camera is in stand-by mode or off, so you have to either guess or press the power button and risk turning the camera off when it was actually only in stand-by, then wait for it to turn on again. The automatic scene settings are unreliable; once it is in macro, it tends to stay there even when pointed at a landscape. As far as I can tell there is no way to turn off the red-eye reduction. Underwater photos are hit-and-miss. Sometimes the photo will come out beautifully and sometimes it will just be grey, even with "underwater" mode manually selected. Water beads up on the lens, causing blurs in the photos. This never happened with my other underwater cameras. I even tried Rain-x on the lens covering as a last resort and it didn't help. From start to finish -- waiting for the camera to power up to looking at blurry photos or remembering missed shots -- using this camera was an exercise in frustration. I'm getting a Canon.

Reviews.Title: Take mediocre pictures in any environment!
Reviews.Author: Jonathan Birge
Reviews.Content: This little camera is as rugged as Fuji claims it is. I've taken it all the way to its ten foot depth limit, banged it around a canoe, dropped it in the dirt, and it functions perfectly. Unfortunately, perfectly in the case of this camera means washed out photos, lots of noise in anything but bright light, and often poor auto-focusing. However, the utility of the camera is such that I still find it a nice addition to the gadget drawer.I understand that a small camera has inherent limitations in image quality to the size of the lens and sensor, but compared to our Canon of similar size, the Fuji takes pictures of noticeably lesser quality. On the other hand, our Canon will be very unhappy in a little bit of rain, let alone underwater. Perhaps the need to harden this camera forced them to compromise on image quality. So, I can't be terribly critical of the FinePix XP10. I just want people to know that you're giving up a certain amount of image quality going with this camera, so make sure that you really need the waterproofing if you're going to buy this. If you just get this as your main digital camera, thinking the durability and weather-proofing will be nice, you will probably be disappointed and wish you'd gotten a camera with better image quality.

Reviews.Title: OK for messing around, but not good enough for anything serious
Reviews.Author: Aaron Silverman "DJ Kuul A"
Reviews.Content: EDIT: Took this on vacation and when we got there, it wouldn't turn on.  Hm, I could've sworn I charged the battery.  So I charged it again.  When the charger said it was finished, I put it back in the camera.  Still nothing.  (Thank god I had my Lumix with me too.) So until I contact Fuji and find out about getting it fixed or replaced, I do NOT recommend this product.*****So the very first thing I did with this camera was drop it the recommended maximum 1 meter onto the concrete surrounding the swimming pool -- not on purpose!  It made a little nick by the tripod hole but otherwise the camera seemed none the worse for wear.  That said, the 1-meter shockproof limit isn't really that impressive.  That's around waist-height for a normal adult.  Better than nothing, though.Next up, in the pool, snapping shots and taking video.  Performance was fine both in and out of the water, although when shooting underwater videos, the sound was a bit noisy and distorted.The camera is small and light, but not too light.  It has enough substance to hold steady nicely.  However, while it is comfortable to hold, some of the buttons are too small and close together.  Hitting the right button (especially the navigation buttons surrounding the Menu/ OK button) is a challenge (I have normal adult-sized fingers).  The menus are clearly laid out and would be easy to use if I didn't keep having to press the Back button after accidentally hitting the wrong button.  Another button issue comes up when shooting videos.  When the camera is in video mode, hitting the shutter button puts it back in photo mode!  To actually start or stop shooting video, you have to press the video button, which is in a very awkward spot on the lower right back of the camera.  It's nearly impossible to press while holding the camera in a normal way -- you have to use both hands.  Setting it up this way was, to be blunt, a moronic decision.So how are the results?  In a word, inconsistent.  Some shots look very nice, while others don't.  (It doesn't hold a candle to my 5MP Panasonic Lumix DMC-FZ20K 5MP Digital Camera with 12x Image Stabilized Optical Zoom (Black), but that's a pricier camera with a far better lens. Of course, I wouldn't want to drop the Lumix on the concrete!)  The good ones print well at 4x6 or 5x7, but 8x10 might be pushing things.  The focus sensor worked pretty well for the most part.  I'd call it "acceptable" for a camera in this price range.One unacceptable attribute was the audio-video synchronization in underwater shooting mode (when shooting in or out of the water).  The audio recording is consistently several seconds ahead of the video, which is especially annoying due to the nice video quality in the bright sunlight at the pool -- and under the water.The included software is easy to install, aside from downloading a very large update.  It's also easy to use.  The only issues with it are that the cable for connecting the camera to the PC is extremely short (less than 2 feet!) and that when it copies the data to the computer, it resets the file creation timestamp to the current date/ time. The "Date Picture Taken" remains accurate, but there's no need to require that extra column.  Simply putting the memory card in a reader and copying the data manually is probably the best bet.  However, you'll need to keep the CD for the manual file.  A printed booklet is included in the package, but it's very slim and doesn't cover most of the camera's features.All told, this is an OK product.  Bearing in mind that it's not terribly expensive, and has some nice features, I wouldn't dismiss it out of hand.  You'll have to consider your specific needs -- if you want to take great pictures, look elsewhere.  If you just want something that will fit in your pocket and isn't likely to break via minor abuse, this might work for you.  As for me, I won't be using this for any sports photography or potential family vacation treasures, but I'll probably carry it around for minor events and activities, just in case.

Reviews.Title: 4.5 stars
Reviews.Author: Deborah Wiley
Reviews.Content: I have been looking for a small, point and shoot digital camera for taking quality pictures when I'm on the go. The Fujifilm FinePix XP10 does just that and more!The Fujifilm FinePix XP10 is user friendly. The functions themselves are fairly self-explanatory although a simple cheat sheet would have been helpful. The large display makes it easy to see when the image is in focus although some may miss the traditional viewfinder, particularly in the bright Florida sunlight.The images are sharper than I expected from a point and shoot as the quality certainly shows in the 12 megapixels. However, in lower lit settings it's definitely better to use the automatic settings or otherwise stabilize the camera as the pictures are likely to blur. I had several blur during a daytime thunderstorm, which surprised me a bit. By adjusting the settings to automatic, I once again had crystal clear images.The zoom works quite well for a basic point and shoot camera but again, a cheat sheet would have made the functions easier to understand. I haven't used the software included with the camera since I have my own and use a Bonzai mobile card reader to transfer the images off of the card. I haven't had trouble with the battery life although others have reported this as an issue. Please note that the power save feature isn't automatically turned on and you must go into the menu to find it. The battery is rechargeable, however, which is a definite plus for me.All in all, the Fujifilm FinePix XP10 is a fun, sturdy camera and hopefully as durable as the appearance indicates.

Reviews.Title: Decent camera for underwater shots.
Reviews.Author: Matt S. K.
Reviews.Content: While this camera doesn't seem to be fazed by infinitessimally small water molecules, sand is its mortal enemy.  Sand got stuck in both the shutter- and power buttons, rendering it useless.  The pictures that I did take with it before its untimely death were very good.  The video was also very clear, but the sound quality was bad-- everything was muffled (except the zoom sound :-/), even outside of water.  Some of the buttons were also hard to press.  I actually had better luck putting my regular camera in a DiPac waterproof case and taking pictures that way.  In the end, I would recommend the case over this camera.

Reviews.Title: subpar audio in video recordings
Reviews.Author: M. Kwak
Reviews.Content: i would have given it 1 star because the audio quality of video was shockingly poor but i gave it 2 because i loved everything else about the camera. i'm no expert but have been a fujifilm user for many, many years. had to replace my f20 only because i dropped it...and so i waited and waited for the release of the xp10. it was a happy day indeed when i finally got my hand on the xp10. camera felt great to the touch, ease of use (buttons & menu), picture quality outdoors & indoors (low lighting) more than decent for my uses (don't really print out large prints, mainly share online & view on-screen). then i decided to record video. i could not believe how bad the sound quality was. i recorded several types of videos and made sure to keep the microphone unobstructed and still the audio was unacceptable. i even went so far as to get my hands on another xp10...and, nope, it wasn't me, it's the camera. basically the audio is great for the first second or two of video playback and then it becomes muffled as if the microphone was blocked.  it gives you the feeling of having clogged ears.  i am very sad to have to return this camera...but for the price i should be able to record videos i can hear.

Reviews.Title: Could be a lot better
Reviews.Author: Burke Engelhardt "Burke"
Reviews.Content: I have several DSLR cameras and wanted something that would fit in my pocket for day to day photography and wanted something that was waterproof so I could take it to the pool or not have to worry about it getting wet or breaking if I dropped it. I do wish I would have spent the extra money and went with something that took better pictures, espc in lower lighting or action shots. I am not saying it is a bad camera, but I think it could do a lot better. I bought my 10 year old son a water proof 6.1MP camera and of course, we lost it so I got this to replace it.The shutter lag is awful and switching over to the video takes about 5 seconds and only shoots video for about 30 seconds at a time. I know I have been spoiled with my DSLR cameras with no lag time for pictures or video, but I think they have a way to go on this P&S.; I have read other reviews on this and people rave about the quality of the pictures and wish I knew how they did it. It needs a flash for everything and being able to adjust the ISO is crazy. The menu is very time consuming and by the time you get the right mode, the photo opportunity has long passed.I bought this solely on price alone and would love to take it back and get maybe the olympus stylus tough. I checked out all the reviews here on amazon and other sites and thought I was buying fuji quality with confidence, but I will do better research next time. I might just have to give this to my 2 year old to use and get the next generation waterproof camera.On the more positive side, we have taken it to the pool a few times and its holding up pretty good. My 2 y/o has dropped it several times and it does keep clicking away. The underwater video is good, but the zoom is so loud and can be heard on the video, but I just wish it would take longer video. The battery is decent and you can find cheap replacements and standbys here on amazon. It is small and compact and fits nicely in your pocket, about the size of my iPhone. It is quick to switch back from view to picture taking mode, but again, the lag has to improve to compete with other digital cameras.If the price goes below a $80, I think it would be a decent value, but if your going to spend more than $100, you might as well get the top of the line and spend the extra money, you won't be sorry.

Reviews.Title: NOT WATERPROOF
Reviews.Author: Amanda Gill
Reviews.Content: I hope I can save someone the mess that my husband and I had with this camera on our wedding/honeymoon in Jamaica. We took the camera snorkeling and five minutes into our swim the camera cut out and filled with water. No doors or compartments came open in the water, it just isn't water tight. Was never more than two feet under the water either. Don't waste your money. Thankfully I took the memory card out back at the hotel and was able to still get the images, but we no longer had a camera the rest of our trip to capture memories :(

Reviews.Title: Couldn't be happier with this camera
Reviews.Author: Pedalinggal
Reviews.Content: I was really worried about purchasing this camera due to the negative reviews. However, there just didn't seem to be great underwater cameras without spending an outrageous amount of money. So, I decided to risk it and buy it...and I'm very glad that I did. I took this camera to Jamaica for a family vacation. I spent a great deal of time snorkeling and hanging out on the beach. It took very good pictures. Lets face it, the quality is not the same as if I had purchased a $500 camera, but for the money I did pay, I have been absolutely thrilled. Based on a review I had read before buying the camera, I followed the advice of one of the reviewers and I just made double-sure that the battery compartment was clicked shut before using it and I have never had a problem with moisture getting into it.Since the family vacation in February, I have taken this camera swimming and boating on a lake and hiking in the mountains. I am not the most careful with cameras when packing so the potential for damage is great, but so far it has withstood even me! The most negative thing I can say about this camera is that it goes through batteries pretty quickly so I have two spare batteries that I keep charged and ready to go. I gave this camera a 4 star only because of the battery life, otherwise it would have been a 5.

Reviews.Title: Not crazy about this camera
Reviews.Author: Don
Reviews.Content: I don't like this camera for two main reasons.1)  When using this camera in water, the lens fogs up from the inside.You can't wipe the lens clear with the fog is on the inside, so the camera is useless until it dries up and the fog clears.  It's very frustrating to try using the camera as it is intended, and get foggy, bad pictures.  Water doesn't kill this camera, it just renders it useless for taking pictures or video.2)  The sound in video mode is not good.When recording a video, you can't hear the sounds of the subject you're trying to record.  You can only hear the lens autofocusing, or hear you zooming in and out.  The noise that the lens focus and zoom makes (which is not that loud) drowns out the audio you are actually trying to record.So - this camera doesn't work well in video mode and doesn't work well in water.Why bother?

Reviews.Title: Disappointing
Reviews.Author: Winter "Winter"
Reviews.Content: I bought a Fujifilm XP10 for use at the beach and around swimming pools, where I was concerned about accidentally dunking a regular camera or my cell phone. I chose the XP10 because I got a good price on it at a well-known members-only discount warehouse. The seals are lightweight and the latches do not secure reliably. You MUST be very careful about keeping the seal clean and double-checking that the latch clicks and catches properly. Fujifilm's design with the lens at the left corner instead of the middle is a poor choice. If you hold the camera with both hands to get a steady shot, your left fingers end up on the lens. Picture quality was mediocre. Contrast and color needed Photoshop correction on most shots regardless of environment. I also had a lot of ruined shots because the focus was blurry. I expect some autofocus trouble with "action" shots at the pool, but not a posed picture on dry land with a steady camera and a clean lens. Overall the XP10 was disappointing, but as a cheap, light-duty waterproof alternative to my Canon I was willing to live with its flaws. I did enjoy taking underwater shots of my daughter with it in a swimming pool, which came out decent after Photoshop. What lead to my 1-star rating was using the XP10 at the beach. I was in waist-high water I got hit from behind by a wave. The flimsy wrist strap didn't hold and the camera was lost. Putting such an inadequate strap on a product that's advertised for snorkeling and beach use is painfully negligent on Fujifilm's part. I'll probably buy a replacement waterproof camera some day, but definitely not another Fujifilm product.

Reviews.Title: HORRIBLE Camera. Not waterproof or sandproof.
Reviews.Author: Shawn
Reviews.Content: This camera was absolutely HORRIBLE. I bought it for a cruise and intended to take it snorkeling with us.Right off, I was a little disappointed with the picture quality. They didn't look good in almost any situation on the boat. Whatever, I thought, it's really intended for the outdoors. Well, I got outdoors and even in bright sunlight the pictures were barely decent. Then, the camera started to show all the problems inherent in the design.Day 1 I had it in my pocket on the beach, and a little sand got in to my pocket. I took the camera out a little while later to take a picture and could not depress the shutter release button. Little bits of sand were underneath the button and only if I pushed VERY hard would it take a picture. I swished the camera around in the water for a while and it helped a little. Next, I decided to take a video and use the controls on the back of the camera. Guess what, sand got under the rubber backing and prevented me from pushing those buttons. I tore off the rubber backing to get all the sand out and cleaned some of it up.Day 2 we went to another port and I had the camera in my pocket. I took it out to take a picture and found that there was more sand underneath the buttons. Couldn't take a picture at all. Had to wait until I got back on the boat and used toothpicks to clean it out.Day 3 we went snorkeling. I had the camera cleaned up and was sure there was no sand in my pocket. We put on the snorkel gear and got in to the water. I took out the camera to take a picture and there was an error code on the screen. Water had gotten in to the memory card compartment and the camera wouldn't work. I had closed it appropriately, the camera just sucks that much. I got no pictures of us snorkeling. Priceless.Thankfully Amazon let me return this horrible piece of junk. I hated everything about it. What is the point of a waterproof camera that isn't waterproof? So very disappointed.

Reviews.Title: Yup.....leaks!
Reviews.Author: LANMan
Reviews.Content: I purchased this camera for use on a snorkeling trip to Mexico. When I received it I was very pleased with the small form factor and also the quality of the few test pictures that I took before the trip. I also purchased the accessory kit and found the silicone case to be a good match that provided good gripping surface and protection.I read most of the reviews here and, while I chalked up most of the complaints about water leaks to either incorrect closure of the battery compartment or excessive depth exposure, to be safe I also purchased the extended warranty. Good thing! On the second day of snorkeling the camera stopped working (of course just as we were taking pictures of a friendly sea turtle). I took the camera back to the hotel room and removed it from the silicone case. It was still not responsive, and the blue power light was stuck in the the lighted mode. There were also what appeared to be a couple of water spots inside the case on the LCD back screen but it was hard to tell since the screen was not illuminated. I carefully completely dried off the camera and opened the battery door and sure enough there was a small drop of water underneath. Now folks there was no way that battery door had been incorrectly secured, I triple checked it before going in the water (and would have to be a complete idiot to make that mistake after reading these reviews plus the very explicit instructions on battery door closure included with the camera). We also were never at a water depth deeper than about 5 feet. The battery door seal and latch just seem to be of poor design.Anyway I removed the SD card and battery...the pictures on the SD card were OK. After drying the inside of the camera I re-inserted the battery and another SD card and it fired up and appears to be fine. Unfortunately I now have lost all confidence in the device. I am over the 30 day return window for Amazon but I will likely exchange it through the extended warranty.One more thing that was mentioned by someone else...the rubbery coating on the control buttons seems to be peeling in a couple of places already...not from wear (it was used TWICE) but just some kind of breakdown of the material.If I had it to do over again I would spend the extra bucks and buy the Canon.

Reviews.Title: Not waterproof
Reviews.Author: pamg
Reviews.Content: I bought this camera to take on a cruise for snorkeling pictures but as soon as I got in, the camera filled up with water and would not turn on.  Since I didn't have a backup clunky disposable underwater camera, I was not able to get any underwater pictures (or any other pictures with this camera) for the entire trip.  Lots of nice features but not reliable at all as a waterproof camera, as they claim.

Reviews.Title: IS THERE AN OPTION FOR ZERO STARS?  P.O.S!!!
Reviews.Author: clynn
Reviews.Content: We bought this camera for our trip to Barbados.  We took some photos before leaving; the night shots are grainy.  This camera did not survive 5 underwater pictures before it quit working.  It is not in any way "waterproof" it isn't even water resistant.  Unfortunately, it was the only camera we brought.  I emailed Fuji that first day and they didn't respond; their customer service sucks as bad as this camera.  Don't put your trust in this camera to record your memories.

Reviews.Title: Not waterproof--failed on its first use
Reviews.Author: LJ
Reviews.Content: I bought this camera for my daughter to take on her honeymoon.  It filled with water on its first use.  It was in only a few feet of water and all compartments were closed.  It had a leak somewhere.

Reviews.Title: Never got to even take a picture.
Reviews.Author: DC
Reviews.Content: Well, this review will only address the warranty (or lack there of) that comes with this camera.I got it, opened the box looked at the camera, put the optional silicone protection sleeve that I bought as well on it and set it on the coffee table. It promptly fell off the coffee table and landed on the floor. A 22inch drop (yes, I measured it.). This shattered the glass covering the lens.  I'm no math wizard but I believe that 22inches is less than 3ft. Perhaps, you need to drop it from no less than 3ft in order for it not to break....Although the camera is advertised as waterproof to 10ft, shockproof to 3ft, and freezeproof to 14deg, the warranty specifically excludes damage due to water, drops, or cold....So I send the camera back to Fuji after having in my possession for roughly 20min. Their response was that the damage was indeed not covered and they "graciously" offered to sell me a refurbished XP10 for ONLY $120 dollars. Which is pretty much what a new one costs. Thanks for nothing Fuji.So yeah, if you want a waterproof, shockproof, and freezeproof camera that isn't guaranteed to be any of those things or warrantied to cover against any of those things, I suppose this might be the one for you.In closing, yes, I dropped it, I am aware, but the camera is advertised as shockproof. If it can't survive a tumble from 22inches WHILE wrapped in a protective silicone sleeve onto the floor inside a house, then what good is it to anyone?

Reviews.Title: Nice little camera
Reviews.Author: Spumoni
Reviews.Content: I bought this camera to take on a two week trip down the Grand Canyon.  It got really wet and was exposed to lots of sand, heat, cold and bumps but kept on shooting.  The image quality was not as good as some of the Canon SLR's other people had. But one of those got a little splashed on the lens the second day out and was dead for the trip.My other reservations:  auto focus was not always reliable and the camera shipped with a DOA charger, so I couldn't use it for three weeks until the snail mail exchange happened.  Lucky I ordered early.  I took extra batteries-non Fuji-and they worked just fine.My tip:  get the Chums float strap. I think it's less than five bucks and will keep your camera from sinking to the bottom of the river.

Reviews.Title: Fuji finepix XP10
Reviews.Author: Lisa M Phillips
Reviews.Content: We purchased this for a cruise in April. It worked great underwater and took good pics! I was concerned about buying it after reading reviews. We were careful to check the gasket each day and it worked great! We took it in the water each day without any problems. I'd buy it again!

Reviews.Title: great job getting me through until the one I really wanted arrived
Reviews.Author: G. M. S. "travel buff"
Reviews.Content: I got this camera because the other underwater camera I had ordered before a snorkeling trip hadn't arrived yet (for long and complicated reasons I won't get into), and I really wanted to be able to take some decent underwater shots.  This camera definitely positively surprised me.  I have always been a Canon fan, so I felt like I was cheating on my brand when I found that I actually really liked it.  It more than just did the job, it did it well and looked good doing it.  Nonetheless, when the other camera (Canon D10) arrived, I sold this camera to a friend at a discount.  While this camera was great, the Canon camera is waterproof further - 33 feet underwater, as opposed to 10 feet with this fuji; and, I am just a big fan of canon and used to their software and features.  I will say this though: The finepix camera is more aesthetically pleasing than the Canon D10 and less bulky, making it more versatile than the D10.

Reviews.Title: fujifilm finepix XP10
Reviews.Author: Ali from CT
Reviews.Content: Great camera.  We purchased this this camera for a 2 week caribbean cruise - our main reason was for taking pictures snorkeling and hiking.This camera went through it all -  it spent hours in the ocean - I forgot not to put it in hot water and it spent some time in a 100+ degree mineral spring - I hit it on a rock when I jumped off a waterfall and it barely got a scratch - at the bottom of our back pack or in an evening bag it held up.It took beautiful pictures underwater and above.  We are very happy with the quality of all our vaction pictures - either at night at dinner or in the disco.  In day light of mountains, waterfalls, and foliage. Clean crisp clear shots.You will not regret buying this camera

Reviews.Title: Strong Camera!
Reviews.Author: Langston
Reviews.Content: The Fugifilm XP10 is awesome! I got it in blue for my 22 birthday last month. The small camera is perfect for my college lifestyle. I don't have to worry about dropping it in some beer, or if I take it to a party, I don't have to worry about people getting it wet. The solid construction of the XP10 is ridiculous. I would recommend it to anyone that wants an affordable, sturdy and handy digital camera.This was the only thing I got for my birthday this year along with an SD card (which you will need), and I don't regret it at all. I got an 8 gig card and with it I can shoot up to about 4500 pictures in one of the lowest pixel counts, which is 3 megapixels. That pixel count looks great. Mind you, the quality is not the best of the best but it is very good. The price CANNOT be beaten for such a cool little camera.The features are great too. you can shoot in black and white, sepia and traditional. All look great, I have been taking a lot in black and white and they look fantastic. The video isn't bad, but the noise from the zooming gets kind of irritating. You can hear the zoom when you watch the playback. I suppose this is due to the fact that it is waterproof and the camera is all sealed up. Annoying, but still, I cannt wait to take this down the river with me and get some cool videos of the water. Can your camera do that? Trust me, this is worth it. After all, they say the best camera is camera you have on you. And if this is true, this bad boy can go ANYWHERE with you.The last thing I want to mention is the autofocus. There is no manual focus on the camera. This is defiantly a point and shoot. Now, I have taken about 100 pictures so far and about 30 of them have come out fuzzy due to the autofocus not doing it's job. This camera is defiantly not for people that want something to do some artist shots with. Although, you could actually get pretty creative. I was able to take some really interesting shots in the shower. The camera can actually pick up water drops in mid air! very cool.Overall, nice camera for the price! Such a strong little guy. I trust it and I am happy with it. The picture quality is good enough for me. I will post some pictures up top for you guys.

Reviews.Title: Bought for a Cruise, works great.
Reviews.Author: Sherry
Reviews.Content: I read the previous reviews, looked at the pictures and compared to other cameras in the same price range.  So I bought this one, green.  It works great for a little camera, occassionaly a picture didn't work or was cloudy but most of them were great.  I even used the video & put it underwater to catch things I couldn't see and it worked really well.  I would recommend this little camera to anyone that wants to use a camera in or near the water.  I also submitted pictures of Stingray City, Grand Cayman & Xcaret in Playa Del Carmen, Mexico.

Reviews.Title: Water proof, small, but lousy optics
Reviews.Author: the Weej
Reviews.Content: My brother, father, and I like to compare snorkeling cameras. The Canon PowerShot D10 is by far the best I've seen - larger and more expensive, but super-crisp images even in lower light. Wow. My fujifilm camera fit in my pocket and was cheaper, but compared to others I've played with, it has poor focus, grainy images, and was basically a disappointment. And since it fell out of my pocket once, it cracked and is no longer waterproof. Not a huge loss since it wasn't very expensive and cameras change fast these days, but I'd just as soon have spent the money on something else.

Reviews.Title: Nice purchase
Reviews.Author: Eileen
Reviews.Content: I bought this camera for my 13 year old daughter who spends quite a bit of time in the water.She has used it for 2 months now and really likes it!  The quality of the photos are not quite as good as her Canon digital camera, but they are good.  Good product for the money.

Reviews.Title: Decent point and shoot. Evolutionary improvement in the Finepix line.
Reviews.Author: Jim Gerdy "jjg"
Reviews.Content: I bought a Finepix with the slide cover about two years ago and found it quite useful as a knock around or for when I don't want to lug around my 4 to 5 lb SLR kit around. Given that I use it when I am not bothering with a higher end camera (I have some Nikons and Leicas for when I feel serious and have the stamina to carry them) I have been pleased with the Finepix line.The older one had what I would call a good interface and decent response time for a point and shoot. This XP10 is a definite improvement. It triggers faster. It's rugged. And the interface allows more custom shooting options. I have to say I have not and probably will not try the waterproof feature. I call it rugged or weatherproof, but don't expect those gasket seals can reliably take a full ten feet of water pressure. If I want to photograph underwater I'll get a proper underwater camera. Anyway this is a nice camera to throw in a bag and take anywhere. And with a moderately large card such as 4 or 8 GB you can hold hundreds of high-res shots or hours of movie. So I'm quite pleased with it and would recommend it as one of the better point and shoots out there.Moreover I'd add that it performs surprisingly well in two types of photography I enjoy particularly, low light and macro. Low light is a bit of a stretch because this little thing is at f/4.5 and you can only do so much. But with ISO 1600 available you can put it on a support and take a long exposure. Again it's nothing like an f/2 or 1.4 on my SLR but fun in itself.For macro I would say it's particularly impressive. It has a "flower" or plain macro mode and a text mode. Both give a very flat field shot at close range. I even have to say for some close-ups I prefer this FinePix to my D300 with my 60mm macro lens because of the focusing mechanism. I have an older macro lens with a slow motor so focusing very close is best done by fixing the focus manually and moving the camera body back and forth. Add to that it's almost three pounds of camera and lens. The FinePix, on the other hand, has a very fast continuous focus and can take a macro shot on the fly pretty well. I know a newer macro lens, with a better motor, would give far better images on my D300. But the FinePix gives decent close-ups for about $150 against the body and lens at some 20x that price with the D300.So I say the FinePix XP10 is an overall fun camera. It's durable and ready to go. And it can even do some specialty photography surprisingly well.

Reviews.Title: Totally Kid-Proof, Small, Only Average Photos
Reviews.Author: Paige Turner "Paige"
Reviews.Content: This little camera is great for kids or outdoor enthusiasts.  It's waterproof, shock-proof (3 ft drop), dust-proof and freeze-proof.  This very small camera is extremely durable and indeed waterproof.  The price is very reasonable as well.  I am not a fan of the very small size because I find it hard to take pictures with, but for smaller hands it is perfect.  It is very portable and so light that it's easy to have it with you all the time.  Like they say, the best camera is the one you have with you.The tradeoff for getting the durability is the shutter button is hard to push (probably due to the waterproof seal gasket) and so it's a little hard to hold the camera still for photos.  I also found the photos shot outdoors in sunlight to be so blown out that it reminded me of a mobile phone camera. (I may be spoiled by the new software on the iPhone- it handles outdoor light better than any point and shoot camera I've seen lately.)If you're looking for a nice little durable, worry-free camera for kid, or for your trip to the beach, this camera is perfect.  I wish I bought this one long ago- I think of all the times it would have been great to have in the water.

Reviews.Title: Love itt
Reviews.Author: buttercupbabe
Reviews.Content: I bought this camera for the waterproof feature & it is AMAZING i've had it since june 2010 i use it all the time & it works just fine. i use it in the pool, beach, in the rain, on the boat, on the four wheelers, its been dropped, banged, threw, & ran over it is a tough camera. the images are good. could be a little better, underwater picture & video are great for the price of this camera. i would recommend this camera to a friend or two. this camera is also good for anyone that has children that will be playing with the camera. i let my little cousins take it & i dont have to worry about them breaking it. its perfect if you love to be outside. the only thing i dont like is the noise when you push the bottons theres no way to turn it off.

Reviews.Title: Fuji XP 10 is OK for the money and taking simple pictures
Reviews.Author: the bear
Reviews.Content: See my extensive comments under the 5 star gadgester review about this product.  i just came back from 10 days in hawaii.  my canon LCD screen went south and i picked this camera primarily for using underwater as an interim camera.my trip was primarily for marlin fishing then doing some snorkling and visiting volcano national park.some of the reviews said the camera leaked under water.  i inspected the cover over the memory card and battery and could not see how it provides a good waterproof seal.  so i did not use the camera for under water shots.  i did not want to mess up my camera before taking the marlin fishing and volcano pictures.  so i bought a fuii $9 27 exposure throw away camera that worked great.  no videos but at least i have underwater pics.this is my brief summary.1.  for regular shots the pictures turned out good.  the camera has trouble with contrasty pictures where you have both shade and bright sun.  this is where cheaper cameras fall down.  the higher pixel count does not mean better quality.  it is all in the size of the CCD itself.  cramming millions of pixels into a small CCD makes for low quality pictures when you try and resolve detail in high contrast situations.  so keep your pictures so there is not a lot of shade and bright light in the picture and you will be fine.2.  i had no problems with battery life but the battery indicator is not accurate.  you can show a 3/4 charge and a few minutes later the battery is gone.  the indicator did not show 1/2 or 1/4 charge  so be careful and take a spare battery.3.  my biggest complaint was seeing the LCD in sunlight.  virtually impossible unless you somehow shaded the screen.4.  the lens is located in the upper left hand corner of the camera as you hold the camera.  it is very easy to get your finger partially blocking the lens since the lens is right where you would hold the camera with your left hand.not sure why the lens was located there.  with the difficulty in seeing the picture with the LCD i had several pictures/vidoes showing one of my figures.  so be careful where you put the fingers on your left hand.4.  sony and panasonic have a video standard called AVCHD that allows recording videos for 30 minutes or more.  this fujii camera uses the older motion MPEG standard which has a 2GB file limitation so you can shoot for about 10-12 minutes.5.  for the money the camera is good.  i gave it a 3 rating because i did not like the design of the cover for the memory and battery, battery charge indicator not being accurate and problems seeing the LCD.  it also did not seem very well built from other reviews with paint peeling off after a couple of hours in the water.  picture quality was good for non contrasty pictures.A BIGGER PROBLEM WITH THESE HD CAMERAS IS HOW ARE YOU GOING TO BURN YOUR VIDEOS TO DVD.  THERE IS NOT A SIMPLE SOLUTION.  I AM DOING RESEARCH RIGHT NOW.  YOU CALL FUJII TECH SUPPORT AND THEY SAY THEY CANNOT HELP YOU WITH ANY QUESTIONS HOW TO BURN A DVD FROM THEIR CAMERA AS THAT FUNCTION IS LICENSED TO OTHERS.  VERY LAME AS THEY GIVE YOU A FEATURE AND THEN DO NOT TELL YOU HOW TO FULLY USE IT.ONCE YOU FIGURE IT OUT YOU WILL NEED AN HD OR BLUE RAY PLAYER TO PLAY YOUR HD DVD'S AND AN HD TV SET.  YOU CAN RUN A CABLE FROM YOUR CAMERA TO THE HD TV BUT YOU ARE STUCK WITH HAVING TO BUY MORE MEMORY IF YOU WANT TO PRESERVE YOUR VIDEO.THE AVCHD LITE FORMAT LOOKS LIKE A BETTER OPTION REGARDING EASE OF BURNING TO A DVD BUT THAT IS LICENSED BY SONY AND PANASONIC.

Reviews.Title: Great little camera until flash stop working
Reviews.Author: maryann toner
Reviews.Content: This was a great little cameras well I thought it was until on the 3rd or 4th day of our vacation the flash just stop working.  Tried playing with it but could not get it to work.  Needless to say I am returning this camera.  Had to go out and purchase another camera while on vacation not happy about that  Took great pictures and videos.  Sometimes it was difficult to see the screen but that happens with all cameras.

Reviews.Title: A good compact digital camera
Reviews.Author: korova
Reviews.Content: Background*My main camera is a 6-year old "prosumer" Nikon. Many photographers will recall that back when my camera was new, digital SLR's were primarily targeted to professionals and compact digital cameras had extremely limited functionality. Prosumer cameras were intended to bridge the gap between these two types of camera by offering image sensors, zoom capabilities, and exposure controls that were better than those on point-and-shoot cameras but just below the level required for professional work.*There aren't really any prosumer cameras on the market these days because point-and-shoot cameras, including the Finepix XP10, now contain a lot of the features that prosumer cameras have. In addition, digital SLR kits have become a lot more affordable. So, prosumer cameras have been squeezed out from both above and below.*Even though the prosumer category has disappeared, the cameras still produce better images than most current compacts due to their relatively large image sensors.My review perspective*I'm using the Finepix XP10 as a fun, casual camera. In other words, I'm using it for times when fine control over composition and exposure isn't necessary (party shots, for example) or in places where there is a high risk of damage to my main camera (such as beaches and pools).*I'm not overly concerned with all the various aspects of image quality when using this camera. I'm not going to spend much time editing or critiquing the photos. If it takes pictures that are attractive to the eye with a minimum of fuss, it's doing its job.What I like*The camera is compact and light. It's roughly the length and width of a computer mouse, with the thickness of a slim TV remote control.*The battery charger is compact as well, around the size of a clamshell cell phone. Even better, the charger has an integrated plug so no cord is necessary.*Picture quality is good enough for snapshots, especially in daylight with stationary subjects.*The camera body is sealed up well, with rubber gaskets protecting buttons and the battery/memory card door, and seems to be rugged.What I don't like*No viewfinder. Call me old school, but I prefer framing shots through a viewfinder. Peering at a screen at arm's length just doesn't feel natural to me.*Screen has low resolution and washes out easily. This sometimes makes it difficult to see if a shot is going to come out the way you want before tripping the shutter.*Doesn't use Compact Flash memory cards. I have a number of CF cards from my main camera and can't use them with the Finepix.*Flash is weak and really only effective close in.*No lens cap or lens cover. The lens is only protected by a pane of glass. It's pretty easy to get this glass dirty or, even worse, scratched if you're not careful.*No good way to set it down unless you buy a case or cover. The camera is fairly thin on the top, bottom, and side edges. This makes the camera easy to carry and hold but forces you to put the camera down on either the lens or the screen.Other notes*The camera comes with only 13Mb of internal memory. A typical high resolution photo taken with this camera is 3Mb, so most users will want to purchase an SD or SDHC memory card as well.*Mac owners don't need to install any software. Apple's iPhoto reads memory cards formatted by the camera without any problems (I use an i7 iMac with System 10.6.4 and iPhoto 8.1.2).*Fujifilm doesn't include many accessories in the base kit. A flotation strap is available as part of the XP10 Accessory Kit.Bottom line*All in all, the Finepix XP10 does exactly what I want it to do. It produces nice snapshots quickly and easily. It can be used in places where I don't want to take my main camera. The things I don't like are common to all point-and-shoot cameras, except for the lack of some kind of built-in protection for the glass covering the lens. Four stars.

Reviews.Title: Good for what it's designed for
Reviews.Author: Christopher K. Vedeler
Reviews.Content: I have a Canon Rebel XSI that takes great pictures.  Unfortunately the Canon is a large expensive camera and isn't something I would want to take to the water park or the beach or mountain climbing and it certainly doesn't fit in my pocket.  I needed a camera that I could use that I wouldn't be afraid to take with me through life's more rustic adventures.I opted for the Fuji FinePix XP10 due mainly for the price and the fact that it is advertised as a small and durable camera.What the camera is good at:1)  If fits nicely in my pocket.  Not much bigger than a cell phone.2)  It is both a digital camera and a video camera.  This saves me big time.3)  It looks cute.4)  It takes decent pictures and video for the price.5)  Controls are intuitive and easy to use.What the camera is not good at:1)  The 12MP is a joke.  Coming from a real 12MP camera (the Canon Rebel) I can tell you that the true resolution of a digital image isn't just about the number of pixels but how sharp the optics are.  The Fuji falls way short here.  Not a huge deal for such an inexpensive camera. I save a tremendous amount of room on the camera by shooting at 6MP, which is really about all the optics can handle.  If you want 12MP, just take your original at 6MP and double the size in Photoshop later.  The quality will be about the same.2)  Zooming while taking a video is a joke.  The zoom motor is clearly heard... I mean it drowns out almost any other sound.  And, it looses focus completely.  If doing video, it is best to leave the zoom alone.3)  Delay between pushing the button and taking the picture.  I must admit I've become quite spoiled with my Canon in this department.  Push the shutter and the picture is taken instantly.  With the Fuji, there is about a 1/4 second delay.  When trying to take a picture of a running kid most of my shots are of their feet or back.  Again this isn't so much a failure of this camera as it is not meant to replace my Canon but it is an annoying limitation.All in all I'm still happy with the camera when I understand and work with it's limitations.

Reviews.Title: Perfect for Snorkel Trips
Reviews.Author: S. Krueger "S. Krueger"
Reviews.Content: I bought this camera to take on our annual trip to St. Johns. Tired of running out of film in disposable cameras, just when the really cool fish showed up, I was ready to make an investment in something that would really take our 3 hour snorkeling trips. This Fuji held up like a trooper!!! I had a floating wrist strap (an absolute MUST so you don't lose your camera!) and was able to pull my camera up and power up in seconds to take some great photos. The spotted rays and sea turtles were no match for my trusty Fuji.I used a 4GB flash card so I got all pics from BOTH snorkeling sessions on one card without having to worry about running out of space. This includes several videos as well. Only downside to underwater video is the sound of the tiny camera motor zooming in and out. Otherwise, absolutely no complaints for this baby.I had it powered on and off hundreds of times while out snorkeling and the battery lasted the entire session. I did re-charge in between so that I wouldn't have any power shortages during second trip.Really like the camera and am SO glad that I chose a new camera over a waterproof case for my current point and shoot.Don't forget to rinse and dry after use in salt water!!!

Reviews.Title: Fabulous for the price!
Reviews.Author: M. M. Jackson
Reviews.Content: I waited a while to write this, to get a fair and accurate assesment of this thing.Overall...wow...for the price this camera goes for, they positively regale you with features and benefits.Shooting underwater at the beach (not having to worry about holding your hand up like a flagpole) was a surprisingly amazing feeling! Pool, beach, etc. Perfect vacation camera.I am extraordinarily pleased with it. The HD video (720p resolution) is just gorgeous.Downsides are: shooting video picks up finger-friction squeak and creak noises, sound recording MAY have changed slightly (?) after shooting underwater, not sure on that one, maybe just subjective, and there is no lens cover so it seems completely susceptible to scratches, however I have closely monitored that part of it and I don't see a single scratch after months of (reasonably rough!) use. If they would just include a neoprene case, it would  be perfect.White balance controls are good...you do have the option of an indoor incandescent setting, although it does seem like it overreaches past natural colors. But what can you expect. Normal shooting mode is very nice. As usual with consumer-grade point and shoots, dark shots can and are fairly grainy, but the resolution is so high that you really won't notice it that much, even for full screen computer viewing and especially not on prints of just abouot any size. Acceptable in my eyes, considering the price and general promises made.The HD video and UNDERWATER (!) are total killer apps that are fun to use and kinda have us "hooked" on this thing. Supposedly you can bang the heck out of it and nothing happens.My wife and I love it, and are very pleased.

Reviews.Title: Great camera - don't purchase from Amazon
Reviews.Author: rklewis
Reviews.Content: This camera is perfect for what you're purchasing it for: intense activity, occasional dunk/splash in water and accidental drops. However, if you've wondered why you can't find a "what's in the box" explanation on Amazon there's a reason for that. You only get the camera and nothing else. Complete waste of money when you can buy an ensemble (case, 4 gig sd card, strap and camera) for less than what Amazon is listing it for. My opinion - do your research on Amazon, read the reviews and if you decide to purchase go ahead and drive to Costco or purchase from another online dealer who is more upfront with what you're actually purchasing. If you're wondering if I'm ticked with Amazon, I'm not. Just sad that after years of perfect purchases this one had to sting me. I should have gone with my 'sixth' sense and realized that if I couldn't find out what came in the package that it probably meant nothing did. lol

Reviews.Title: Apprehension Proved Unwarranted
Reviews.Author: J. Boyd
Reviews.Content: I bought this camera before our annual trip to the Caribbean.  I wanted something to use instead of my DSR at poolside. I was very concerned based on the other reviews on this site, but it still seemed like the best option.  Before I bought it, I was particularly impressed by the quality of photographs and videos taken with it that are posted on YouTube.  I have been VERY happy with this camera.  It takes excellent underwater shots and videos.  I always use due care to prevent water intrusion:  I keep it out of the water whenever possible; I never swim vigorously with it to keep water from being forced inside; and I keep it in a pocket or safe place when doing rough activities such as whitewater rafting.  And I have taken it swimming, sailing and whitewater rafting with excellent results! I highly recommend this camera for underwater, and outdoor shots.  It is not a great all-around camera, and usually doesn't take very good low-light or inside photographs.  However, if you buy it for what it is intended and treat it with due care, I believe you will be very pleased with its performance!

Reviews.Title: Great Little Gadget
Reviews.Author: Chris S.
Reviews.Content: I just purchased this camera from costco for 139.99. It came with a 4gb card, carrying case, charging unit, and a usb cable. So far so good.The picture quality is pretty good for the size and price of the camera. In the daylight the pictures are great. The video quality isn't too bad either.The HD video is a great bonus. I was looking for a good camera that could work underwater (we go on a lot of vacations that have swimming pools, beaches, water parks, etc.) HD videos take up a lot of space, with my 4gb card it can only take 12 minutes of video. There's a dedicated video button so you don't have to search around for a video mode for those spontaneous moments where you want to capture video on the fly.One thing to note about video: The speaker on this thing sucks. No joke, there's some white noise that I always hear when I playback my videos but this isn't a big deal to me because I'll probably put some music over it whenever I edit my videos.Design is sleek. I purchased the black one because I like those generic colors, but the other ones look great too all with glossy finishes. The camera itself is tiny but the LCD screen is a great size so you can clearly see your pictures and easily read the options and settings.If your looking for a very portable camera for active use (sporting, vacations, hiking, underwater) then this is a great buy, for it's price. The only real bad thing is the sound during recording. But, it's a camera not a camcorder. If you're hesitant about buying this, give it a try.The only time I hear bad reviews about this product is if it was defected somehow. Luckily, so far I haven't had any problems. So I'm writing this review based on a unit that is working 100% properly. Everyone is bound to find a defected electronic device sometime in their life so if it doesn't work the first time, return for a new one.I recommend it this product!

Reviews.Title: Broke after a few days
Reviews.Content: We bought this camera for our honeymoon to Tahiti expecting to use it a lot for snorkling.  It worked well and took great pictures underwater.  Then, disaster struck.  First, the LCD display died; but the camera seemed to be operational (just no LCD).  But soon enough, the whole thing died.  Luckily we got some usage out of it (about 5 days) before it died.  We were totally bummed out because the camera did take great pictures and was fun and easy to use.  We actually didn't buy the camera from Amazon.  We bought it from Costco.  When we returned it, the cashier said that they've been getting back a lot of these camera's.  So while the camera does take great pics, beware!!

Reviews.Title: didn't deliver what it promised.
Reviews.Author: Liz in FL "lizinfl"
Reviews.Content: I had this 2 weeks, went in the pool once in less than 2ft of water took a photo, dried out the camera like detailed in the manual.  3 days later the camera made a gear grinding sound with an error message not in the manual. contacted fujifilm via email, recvd response in 30 minutes to ship it to them for repair.  in less than 2 weeks recvd camera back and after taking the 3rd picture the error message came back on the screen.  I purchased this at costco which has a 90 day return policy so i returned it and went with the pentax w90 based on reviews here & outside magazine.i gave the camera a chance, the purchase of this camera was because i have a 2yr old and a 9 month old and they constantly drop electronics, so I wanted a rugged camera that could fit in my pocket.  the canon is the ideal rugged camera however it's extrememly bulky.  don't waste your time purchasing this camera.  i did my research before i bought it but still gave it a chance because of the price point, not worth the hassle.  the pictures were not that great.  The SR AUTO mode got confused and would take pictures without the flash and camera is slow in between shots.  This was reported by other reviewers here and on cnet.  Once I use the pentax W90 a while I will post that review.

Reviews.Title: water proof camera
Reviews.Author: review
Reviews.Content: Fujifilm FinePix XP10 12 MP Waterproof Digital Camera with 5x Optical Zoom and 2.7-Inch LCD (Green)This camera was used only for one week and it leaked and stopped working. I did not exceed more than 2 feet below water level in a pool and ocean. Do not purchase.

Reviews.Title: Good camera for the price
Reviews.Author: Alison A. Feix
Reviews.Content: This was a gift for my daughter.  Being very active with people with special needs, she loves to take pictures of her friends by the pool.  Her friends also enjoy taking pictures under water.

Reviews.Title: Underwater
Reviews.Author: kboz
Reviews.Content: This camera has been to the Bahamas and the Florida Keys with me a couple times since my purchase. Works great underwater, even the video was impressive!

Reviews.Title: Nice
Reviews.Author: Cheryl Palumbo
Reviews.Content: I have had this camera for awhile now and still am very happy with it. Battery time is good and it is an easy camera to operate.

Reviews.Title: wow!!
Reviews.Author: out door mom
Reviews.Content: I'm not sure about the other reviews but I have had this camera for over 7 years I have never had an issue the pictures are beautiful out of the water as they are in the water, this camera have been to rivers lakes the beach swimming pools and the pictures have been crisp clear and they have download to my Xbox computer laptop just fine, at night the pics are amazingly clear the light have never been an issue maybe I got one of the few well made but I will recommend this camera to anyone.  I'm not sure about thewaters depth but as far as 10 feet for me have no issue.

Reviews.Title: Great!
Reviews.Author: john R. swim
Reviews.Content: Excellent camera for the $$. The double lock for battery case is a bit of a hassle but this only means they are trying harder to keep the Beautiful Pacific Ocean out of the innards.

Reviews.Title: Bad pictures and horrible waterproofing
Reviews.Author: PhoenixM "PhoenixM"
Reviews.Content: From the beginning, I was underwhelmed at the quality of pictures that this camera took. Bright daylight was about the only time it worked well; anytime I took pictures indoors, I soon got in the habit of snapping four or five of them at a time, in the hopes that maybe one of them would look halfway-decent. There was a distinct orange/reddish tint to most of my pictures, and it didn't matter what shooting mode the camera was in or what adjustments I tried making to it. The pictures simply tended to be garbage (and video quality looked just as bad the couple of times I tried using that as well). But, at least at first, it did seem to be reasonably waterproof; it got wet when I got caught in the rain a few times, and still seemed to work fine afterwards.About eleven months after I bought it, it one day simply stopped working. It had been sitting in a drawer for a few weeks, so at first I thought that maybe it was the battery (battery life was abysmal as well, by the way). But it simply would not turn on, even after the battery was fully charged. I called Fuji, and they wouldn't offer me any guarantees that any repairs would be covered under warranty, but they did offer to at least look at it for free. Three weeks after I sent it, I still hadn't heard anything back, so I called them - and was told, quite literally, that no tech people had gotten around to taking it out of the box yet, but that they'd get on it right away! In all fairness, they did get to it right away after I called, but I was annoyed that I'd had to call in the first place just to get them to pay any attention to my camera.A few days later, Fuji sent back my camera, with the motherboard replaced, at no charge due to the fact that it was still (barely) within the first twelve months of ownership. If my camera had waited just a few more weeks to die, and/or if I'd discovered it was broken just a few weeks later than I actually did, I guess I would have been completely up a creek.Speaking of creeks... my newly-fixed camera worked for a little over a year afterwards, and then died on a camping trip when I had the gall to take my allegedly waterproof camera into a lake with me to snap pictures of fish. The camera was theoretically rated for up to 3 meters down (10 feet-ish), and I certainly did not go deeper than that in the lake while it was in my bathing suit pocket; but come the next morning, there was condensation inside the lens and inside the LCD, and the camera was unresponsive. Keep in mind that this allegedly "waterproof" camera actually had a shooting mode for taking pictures underwater, so it's not as if Fuji was exactly trying to *discourage* people from using it underwater.So, yeah, in summary: horrible pictures, and "waterproofing" that didn't actually protect it from full submersion.

Reviews.Title: Don't waste your money on this dog!
Reviews.Author: David Flory
Reviews.Content: I've had this camera about two years.  It has been alright as far as function and photo quality.  It quit working while I was snorkeling on the surface in Puerto Vallerta.  The battery door leaked and it died.  The newer model has two latches on the door, seems like the Fuji folks realized their design shortcomings and hopefully addressed the problem.  This was not a cheap camera when I purchased it at Costco.  Unfortunately the statute of limitations ran out, and I was unable to return it there.  Now it's just a little green paperweight.  Spend your money on another brand, Fujifilm has seen the last of my business.

Reviews.Title: If you want a waterproof camera... find another one!
Reviews.Author: Superboy32
Reviews.Content: This camera is terrible on every level. This camera is marketed as a waterproof camera and it fails to live up to it's claims. I've purchased two of these cameras and both fail on their picture quality and camera functionality. I used the camera once for snorkeling in Jamaica and it performed decent under water but the second time I used it for snorkeling, the housing allowed water to get inside the mechanism and the camera completely shut down and trashed. The camera performs terrible in, indoor lighting, poor shutter performance (lots of blurred pictures), lots of little light orbs/bubbles imposed on the image and lots of over or under bright pictures. <---- These reviews stand for both cameras that I purchased. I would definitely not buy another one of these cameras again. It's difficult to find assistance from the company to discuss the issues other than, "return it back to the store." After or under a year, a store isn't going to take the product back even when the camera is a piece of junk. VERY FRUSTRATING!

Reviews.Title: Only takes decent pictures during the day
Reviews.Author: Jason
Reviews.Content: This camera takes awful pictures in low light conditions.  It is OK during the day.  I would have to say I would not recommend this product to anyone.  Also, the battery is not holding its charge very well.  This might be because I rarely use it since the picture quality is mediocre at best.

Reviews.Title: Used it for years
Reviews.Author: anna rice
Reviews.Content: This little camera has been everywhere. It is small and handy and boy is it durable. It takes good quality pictures and has quite a few choices for settings. It is not overly complicated, so you don't need a degree to use it (unlike some other cameras that I have had.)

Reviews.Title: IDEAL VACATION CAMERA! Great for underwater!
Reviews.Author: Corrie "Corrielee"
Reviews.Content: I bought this camera for a trip to Hawaii.  It took great underwater photos of us snorkeling and we could see all the fish! Even the eye detail it was kind of spooky to look at some of the pics!  The regular photos outside the water weren't too bad either.  Of course there are way better cameras out there, but for the price, and the fact you can take it in the sand, underwater, etc and not worry about your fancy camera getting ruined.it can't be beat.  Perfect second camera to take with you on beach/water vacations, and perfect for kids.

Reviews.Title: Lasted a year
Reviews.Author: J. Crawford
Reviews.Content: I thought this was a pretty good camera for the price. I gave it to my son to take on a canoe trip and he used it a lot during the year, took a lot of decent outdoor photos and videos. Even with heavy use by a teenager, consumer electronics should last longer, so I only give it three stars.

Reviews.Title: not waterproof
Reviews.Author: Aaron
Reviews.Content: I took this camera snorkeling and it started to not work after having it in the water for about an hour.  I had to dry it out for a few days for it to work again.  It is not waterproof- only water resistant unlike advertised.

Reviews.Title: put to the test and passed
Reviews.Author: Kandi
Reviews.Content: I have had this camera for about a year now and have used it underwater in the ocean, lakes, rivers and many swimming pools/waterparks. I have yet to have a single problem with this camera. It takes decent pictures that are perfect for my casual use of this camera. It is an awesome camera for a mommy with small kiddos! Whom I can actually let use this camera without worry. I bought this camera specifically for our outdoor adventures but have ended up using it for pretty much everything and my Nikon has been rarely used this year.

Reviews.Title: Great Camera for Snorkeling
Reviews.Author: erenquist
Reviews.Content: I needed a reasonably priced camera for my vacation, specifically for snorkeling. I had two options, either find an underwater case for my Canon G9 (all which were expensive) or get a cheap disposable. I wanted something in between--to avoid spending a fortune and take quality photographs, thankfully this Fuji Film fit the bill on both.This is great for the price, my primary use was for underwater recording--both still images and video. I used the G9 for all other photography on my trip. I recommend shooting at the highest quality and bringing more than 1 memory disk or a computer to upload and save. The battery life is good--lasted most of the afternoon. It wouldn't hurt to have an extra battery on hand if expect to be out for an entire day.

Reviews.Title: Mediocre point and shoot, but excellent underwater photos
Reviews.Author: Caleb McKay "cmckay"
Reviews.Content: Okay, out of the water, pictures are pretty much garbage unless you fiddle with the settings every time. Leaving it on auto will not get you worthwhile photos, and the shutter speed is relatively slow. Now, if you are like me and are looking for a camera for taking decent underwater pictures, then this camera is great.Not sure about the users who claim water damage. Bad unit? Dropping water with force or exceeding a few feet depth?All I know is my wife and I got this camera for a trip to Puerto Rico where we took it snorkeling on the reefs. Withstood constant use swimming in salt water. Cleaned per instructions in manual, and it still works fine after over year of heavy pool use.I did get a little condensation once that in the lens that left a blur on photos. Let it dry completely and never had the problem again. Betting one of the kids splashed a little hard.All in all, it won't replace your normal camera, but for some good underwater shots at a low price, I would recommend this camera.

Reviews.Title: Terrible
Reviews.Author: Mandy L Gonzales
Reviews.Content: We bought this camera for our trip to Six Flags waterpark. After 10 minutes in the water..not even submerging..the camera was soaked inside and out and ruined. Not worth the box it came in.

Reviews.Title: Poor Battery LIfe
Reviews.Author: Hugh G. Stockton
Reviews.Content: Neither the included battery, nor the extra one I ordered will last more than three days even with only very minimal usage - less than 12 shots per day.

Reviews.Title: Expensive for a disposable camera
Reviews.Author: Charlie™
Reviews.Content: The XP10 is very cheap for a digital camera - and very, very cheap for a waterproof one. Unfortunately, it's quite pricey for a disposable camera, which is what mine seems to have turned out to be. I bought it for a snorkeling and kayaking trip to Hawaii - thinking it wiser than employing one of the fancy zip-lock "camera bags" for my better quality equipment.  Hard to say, in the end.Photo quality, buttons, menus, features are all quite marginal. Not bad for the price, but not up to current standards either. The underwater shots I got seemed surprisingly good (to me), but those taken above the surface were not up to the quality of even my older Canon point-and-shoots. The tiny, tiny lens is very difficult to get sufficiently dry after a dunking to then take dry shots without water droplets in the frame. The buttons and d-pad are awfully small for even my fairly small fingers. The LCD screen is awful - not bright enough for daylight and too reflective to use underwater - and there is not rangefinder to use when you can't see the LCD. The actual images produced are large, but we have a case of megapixel inflation again - a large number of low quality pixels on a very small image sensor do not a better camera make.  Still and all, had it lasted more than a week on vacation, it would have  been good value for easy underwater or surf snapshots... and it was fun to play with.Unfortunately, despite being obsessive about only opening and closing the battery/memory door either indoors or inside the car (where I could be sure to keep seals and hinges clean), the system failed after about 4 shallow snorkeling expeditions - and before our long kayak trip around Na'Pali.  Simply stopped turning on. Moisture could be seen at the bottom of the battery bay with a flashlight, although it was not really full of water.  Ironically I ended up buying and using a Fujifilm disposable camera for the kayak trip. The photos were only slightly inferior to what the digital camera had been producing.Afraid I can't recommend it for anything other than perhaps outdoor use where only light rain or extremes of temperature might be an issue. Sending this one back for repair (too late to return it). Anyone want a used one?

Reviews.Title: Fujifilm Finepix 5x zoom
Reviews.Author: Lara E. Bee
Reviews.Content: I bought this camera back in February, 2011, have only had it for 4 months and the camera has already stopped working. It took great pictures while it worked but am not happy about having to contact the manufacturer for repairs on a new camera. I will stick with buying Kodak Point-n-Shoot cameras in the future. I have had these cameras for several years and have never had to send one in for repairs. Don't buy this camera. It's not worth the money.

Reviews.Title: It's really not a very good camera
Reviews.Author: Big Pa
Reviews.Content: So far mine remains waterproof but the picture quality is no better than a disposable camera.  Pictures are very grainy unless taken in bright sunshine.  Autofocus is slow and not accurate so expect a lot of out-of-focus shots. A lot of "modes" but none give outstanding results.  All in all, it's a cheap camera that usually takes bad pictures.

Reviews.Title: Small and Lightweight
Reviews.Author: A. Butler
Reviews.Content: I am actually afraid to test it in water since my Olympus broke. I am leary of the water test. I am sure it works fine though. The picture quality is great as long as your subject is not moving at all. The video is aweseom though, even shooting in High Def.

Reviews.Title: Nice little camera until it stopped working
Reviews.Author: Pat Damiani
Reviews.Content: I bought this camera to take on a trip to Kauai, specifically to use while snorkeling. The camera worked great for about a week, including two times in the water. But on the third time in the water, the whole screen fogged up and the camera quit working. Don't buy this camera if you intend to use it in the water.

Reviews.Title: Caveat Emptor
Reviews.Author: Scott Edwards "Scott Edwards"
Reviews.Content: I bought this camera and in less than 60 days the LCD viewfinder screen blew out. Fuji told me that it was still under warranty, but, it would take 6-8 weeks to fix it. I tried returning it only to find out that it's out of stock most places, and would take weeks to get another. I picked this camera because it is the waterproof version of my daughter's, and it works great. I think Fuji cut a lot of internal corners to make this one waterproof. After 3 uses to have it zotz is just unacceptable. Look elsewhere for this camera, it's a piece of garbage.

Reviews.Title: Rip Off Camera
Reviews.Author: Mark W. Ginsberg
Reviews.Content: First of all, they say you can see the monitor in broad daylight.  Not at all true.Secondly, the charger failed to work after a few months.  Fuji will not pay for postage and demands a copy of the receipt, even though it was registered with them on line.

Reviews.Title: Look for another waterproof camera
Reviews.Author: Gregory House "discerning shopper"
Reviews.Content: Don't be fooled by those pics of water on the camera - mine lasted for a short while under water, and then eventually both water and sand got into the battery compartment. Camera went dead in the middle of a super vacation, so you're taking a risk if it's your only camera on the trip. Picture quality was suprisingly poor for 12MP, even my old iphone generation 1 camera takes better pictures. Waste of time and effort.

Reviews.Title: love it.
Reviews.Author: Welsh
Reviews.Content: My husband got me this camera for my birthday. i didn't like it much at first because i thought all the pics came out blurry. but after figuring it out, i LOVE it. i have another camera i use around the house but it's kinda bulky to put in my purse for day trips & such. this one is small enough to fit in my purse, pocket & my 2year old son can't break it (he already put it to the test by throwing it off a deck!). i havn't used it underwater yet. i also have the rubber case for it, when i have the case on sometimes it makes the pictures snowy, but it's not a big deal, i still love it! this camera is so perfect to catch all my little ones memories :) i don't use the video camera much, that's why i gave it 3 stars & didn't rate waterproof because i havn't tested it. overall, it's worth the $.

Reviews.Title: Best $100 spent!
Reviews.Author: KimTruc
Reviews.Content: My husband and I booked our first trip to Aruba for our honeymoon (married April 23, 2011 !) and knew we wanted an underwater camera. I hate reviews. It really does depend on who it is writing the review and what they wanted the camera for. We went snorkeling on our trip. This camera was on my wrist under water for practically 3 hours at one time, no problems. Took pictures and video underwater, no problems. Took pictures and video out of water, no problems. The shutter is a bit slow, but if you have all this special mechanism and protection for this thing to be submerged under water, frozen or dropped, it has to have some sort of delay. We loved it and more than once on our honeymoon I said, "Best $100 spent!" and actually meant it. I loved the feature of the little tone it makes when it turns on. That is VERY helpful when you are submerged under water in sunny skies and there is a bit of a glare, you can't easily see if the camera was on or not. The noise told me it was!Thank you Fuji for creating this little gadget and not making it ridiculously priced. It helped capture awesome moments on our honeymoon!Kim

Reviews.Title: A nice little p & s
Reviews.Author: Terri
Reviews.Content: This is a nice camera to keep in one's bag for those shoot-on-the-run pictures. I've had it for a month now, and the only thing I don't like about it is the akward location of the lens. I'm left-handed, and my finger tends to cover the lens opening.

Reviews.Title: Freaking Awesome!
Reviews.Author: Ashley Billings
Reviews.Content: I bought this camera about a year ago and decided to write a review for it.  The reason I bought this one in the first place is I kept dropping my other cameras and breaking them, and I noticed this one said shockproof, which is a VERY important feature to me bc im such a klutz lol.  Then I noticed it also says waterproof, which I didnt understand how a electric digital camera could be waterproof, but I took a chance and I bought it.  At first I was scared to emerge it in water, but once I did it still worked just fine so that part is true.
